headline: A Modest Proposal to Survive the 487 Days Till the Election. (But Who’s Counting?)
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Let’s all take a break from politics.
lead_paragraph: PETOSKEY, Mich. — For this Fourth of July, amid picnics and parties marking Independence Day around the country, let me offer a Modest Proposal.

headline: Summer ’19 Brought To You By Nostalgia-Bait Movies
keywords: ['Movies', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Pokemon (Fictional Characters)', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties']
abstract: How much joy is left to be squeezed out of watching photo-realistic animals, or new Hollywood stars, act out old movies we loved, beat for beat?
lead_paragraph: Hollywood is, self-evidently, in the middle of a nostalgia boom. A time traveler from the mid-1990s who suddenly lands in the mezzanine of any given AMC theater this year should be forgiven for thinking his experiment failed as he watches audiences pour into theaters for “The Addams Family,” “The Lion King,” and “Men in Black” — all 2019 rejiggerings of two-decade-old movies.

headline: Robespierre’s America
abstract: We need to reclaim the spirit of 1776, not the certitudes of 1789.
lead_paragraph: I was walking through an airport terminal trying to catch a connecting flight last Saturday when I spotted a writer I had never met but whose work I admire. He greeted me with a look of fatherly concern: “Sorry about what’s happening to you on Twitter.”

headline: Is Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s ‘Fascism’ Claim Too Extreme?
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Philosophy']
abstract: ICE is not the SS or the Gestapo. But it has concerning similarities.
lead_paragraph: On July 2, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, after a visit to migrant detention facilities run by Customs and Border Protection in Texas, claimed that the United States is “headed toward fascism.” Much of the response that followed was expected, but little or none of it examined the statement closely or detailed to what degree the United States’ immigration policy justifies such comparisons. So how apt is this analogy between the current situation and early years of fascist regimes?

headline: Why Trump Likes Tanks
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)']
abstract: Those hulking relics are part of the insidious nostalgia that undergirds his “Make America Great Again” ideology.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: How the Catholic Church Lost Italy to the Far Right
abstract: Pope Francis’ retreat from culture-war politics has left a void that politicians have been all too eager to fill.
lead_paragraph: On paper, Italy’s deputy prime minister, Matteo Salvini, is a dubious poster child for Catholicism. Mr. Salvini is divorced. He has two children by two women and is in a relationship with a third. But that hasn’t stopped him from reinventing himself as Italy’s Catholic-in-chief. “I am the last of the good Christians,” Mr. Salvini, 46, said recently, during an appearance on the popular TV show “Non è l’Arena.” “I defend our history and the existence of Catholic schools,” he said during the same appearance. “If I believe in God,” he asked rhetorically, “and if I even ask for Mary’s protection, does that bother anybody?”

headline: Stop Calling Politics Our New Religion
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Atheism', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: It’s offensive to both politics and religion.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a new villain to account for the polarization and sheer meanness of our current politics? Instead of blaming deep divisions over race, misogyny, immigration, income inequality and the bellicose Twitter reign of President Trump, many have seized on secularism as a scapegoat for everything that keeps politically conscious and conscientious Americans awake at night.

headline: A Clash of Worldviews as Pope Francis and Putin Meet Again
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A meeting between Russia’s president, seen as the spiritual strongman of European nationalists, and the pope, a moral voice against populism, comes amid an ideological divide in the West.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis is viewed by many European liberals as the greatest moral voice against the resurgence in populism and the demonization of migrants.

headline: ‘Cold Blood’ Review: The Hit Man and the Hottie
abstract: A drained-looking Jean Reno anchors this stagnant thriller from the French director Frédéric Petitjean.
lead_paragraph: According to the publicity notes, the decision to film the French director Frédéric Petitjean’s “Cold Blood” in English was a no-brainer. Audiences might disagree.

headline: ‘The Cat Rescuers’ Review: A Portrait of New York’s Street Cats and Their Loyal Humans
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Cats', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: New York is teeming with stray cats. Meet the people trying to do something about it.
lead_paragraph: New York’s cat lovers are probably familiar with the feeling of wanting to help out the city’s many stray felines, but Rob Fruchtman and Steven Lawrence’s modest, effective documentary “The Cat Rescuers” captures the peculiar anxiety of not being able to help all of them. The film focuses on the brave, sometimes eccentric souls who have devoted their lives to caring for the city’s cat population. As we watch their often heroic efforts, we get the nauseating sense that whatever they do will never be enough.

headline: ‘Phil’ Review: A Messy Story About a Suicidal Dentist
abstract: Greg Kinnear strains to convey the title character’s inner torment while making him outwardly comic.
lead_paragraph: In “Phil,” Greg Kinnear acts and directs, which has left him without at least one important person to say “no.” Still, even the most exacting auteur might have labored to help him make sense of this title character. The film opens with Phil, a suicidal dentist, preparing to throw himself off a bridge, then backing off, despite the encouragement of onlookers and the thematically appropriate musical accompaniment of “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden” on his car radio.

headline: Sundance Short Film Festival Review: Bite-Size Samplings From Park City
abstract: This lineup of traveling shorts from America’s pre-eminent showcase for independent cinema is a decidedly mixed bag.
lead_paragraph: At the Sundance Film Festival, shorts have to gasp to get any of the high-altitude oxygen; journalists tend to lavish their hype on features. So the festival’s annual traveling shorts program functions as a kind of counterweight. This year’s grab bag, like those of years past, is a mixed one, of award winners, nonwinners, promising shorts and meh shorts. Say this for the lineup: Of the seven movies here, no two are remotely alike.

headline: Pakistan Brings Terrorism Financing Charges Against Hafiz Saeed
abstract: Facing the threat of sanctions for not cracking down on militants, Pakistan is again moving against the founder of the terrorist group Lashkar-e-Taiba.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Under pressure from the United States and a global watchdog group, Pakistan is prosecuting the founder of the Islamist terrorist group that carried out the deadly 2008 Mumbai attacks on charges of terrorism financing, along with several of his close aides.

headline: The Peacemaker at the Center of Hong Kong’s Turbulent Protests
abstract: Roy Kwong, a 36-year-old legislator, has emerged as a hero for the city’s youth and a leading voice for moderation during the political crisis there.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As protesters smashed their way into Hong Kong’s legislature this week, a young politician rushed to the front lines with a desperate plea.

headline: Hong Kong Police Announce First Arrest in Storming of Legislature
abstract: Protesters girded themselves for the possibility of more detentions and what they feared would be a citywide dragnet.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police have announced their first arrest in connection with Monday’s assault on the territory’s legislative building, as protesters gird themselves for the possibility of more detentions and what they fear will be a citywide dragnet.

headline: Gibraltar Seizes Syria-Bound Tanker Thought to Be Carrying Iranian Oil
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Officials said the tanker was detained under European Union sanctions on Syria. Shipping monitors said it was also trying to skirt United States sanctions on Iran.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British marines and the port authorities in Gibraltar on Thursday detained a supertanker that was carrying crude oil from Iran to Syria, a violation of European Union sanctions against Syria. The seizure of the ship threatened to raise tensions between Iran and the West.

headline: ‘Stranger Things’: Mrs. Wheeler and Billy Pick Up Where They Left Off
abstract: Cara Buono, who plays Mrs. Wheeler, discusses Season 3 and her part in one of the show’s most provocative pairings.
lead_paragraph: The pool glistens in a sultry teaser for “Stranger Things” as revelers splash and frolic beneath the summer sun. The camera briskly pans to a phalanx of leisurely ladies perched atop their chaises. In the center, Karen Wheeler, played by Cara Buono, purses her carefully crafted lips and lies in a suggestive pose. She wants to be seen.

headline: Her Kind of Comedy: Lewd, Vulnerable and Self-Aware
abstract: Jacqueline Novak is poised for a breakout with “Get on Your Knees,” a new one-woman show Off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The comic Jacqueline Novak doesn’t like the term “oral sex.”

headline: Shrink an Orchestra to a Single Piano, Keeping the Magic
abstract: Playing transcriptions of symphonies or ballets used to seem gimmicky. Younger pianists see it differently.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, when I interviewed the pianist Vladimir Horowitz at his elegant Manhattan townhouse, I asked him if he had any regrets. His answer surprised me. He said he deeply regretted never having played Liszt’s transcriptions of the Beethoven symphonies in public.

headline: The Democrats’ Leftward Move

lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Producer, Riza Aziz, Is Charged in Malaysia Fund Scandal
abstract: Mr. Riza, whose stepfather is a former prime minister of Malaysia, pleaded not guilty to money-laundering charges in the disappearance of billions from a government fund.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Hollywood producer Riza Aziz, stepson of the former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak, pleaded not guilty on Friday to five counts of laundering money misappropriated from a Malaysian government investment fund.

headline: At Valentino, Diversity by Design
abstract: At Viktor & Rolf, sustainability. Finally, designers are engaging with the issues of the day instead of ignoring them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Issues of inclusion and cultural sensitivity — and fashion’s lack of understanding thereof — have been at the forefront of the general conversation for awhile now, though they have been particularly pressing since last fall, when the industry began what seemed like a run of increasingly tone-deaf products accompanied by a slew of mea culpas.

headline: Why Doesn’t He Love Our Kids Like He Loves His Nephew?
abstract: A reader feels slighted by her husband’s doting on another child.
lead_paragraph: My husband’s brother died in his 30s, eight years ago, leaving a wife and 5-year-old son. Ever since, my husband visits his nephew, without fail, one night a week for a couple of hours. (The boy is great and doing well.) Meanwhile, we have two kids in elementary school, and my husband never gives them a two-hour stretch of undivided attention. One of our kids has autism, so it’s tricky to connect with him emotionally. But my husband doesn’t seem to try. I’m really hurt that he doesn’t spend more time with his own kids. I don’t want to say anything, though. It may put him on the defensive and make things worse. Thoughts?

headline: It Was a Robust Democracy. Then the New President Took Power.
abstract: Benin has prided itself on its freedoms, but the increasingly autocratic grip of the West African country’s president is threatening that.
lead_paragraph: COTONOU, Benin — After 52 days under virtual house arrest, the former president of the West African nation of Benin was set free and fled across the border to Togo last week without a word to his supporters or the media.

headline: Which States Are the Safest?
abstract: A new study examines crime, accident rates, natural disasters and financial risks in each of the 50 U.S. states.
lead_paragraph: A recent study analyzed 52 metrics to determine the safest states in the country, as well as the least safe. The results might surprise you.

headline: Damaged Russian Submersible Has Nuclear Power Unit, but It’s Intact, Kremlin Says
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Radiation']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said that the submersible, described as a secret research vessel, was nuclear-powered. But the government was still withholding details.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian military submersible that suffered a deadly fire in the Arctic has a nuclear-powered engine, President Vladimir V. Putin revealed on Thursday, but his defense minister said the power unit was not seriously affected by the accident.

headline: Justin Amash, a Trump Critic on the Right, Leaves the G.O.P.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Mr. Amash, a libertarian representative from Michigan, has faced fierce attacks from President Trump since becoming the first Republican in Congress to call for impeachment.
lead_paragraph: Representative Justin Amash of Michigan, the only sitting Republican member of Congress to support impeaching President Trump, announced on Thursday that he was leaving the party after facing fierce attacks from the president and fellow Republicans.

headline: As BTS’s Reach Expands, an Army of Dedicated K-Pop Translators Grows
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Social Media']
abstract: The fans who devote their time to interpreting lyrics, tweets and interviews for listeners who don’t speak Korean are hard-working, passionate and unpaid.
lead_paragraph: In June, the Korean pop group BTS observed its sixth anniversary with an annual celebration called Festa — 10 days of new interviews, behind-the-scenes clips, choreography videos and the release of its member Jin’s first solo song, “Tonight.” The group also held its fifth “Muster” fan gathering, continued its Love Yourself: Speak Yourself tour and released a new mobile game.

headline: He Enjoys American Coffee and Restaurants. Is He a Credible Negotiator for Iran?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian most closely associated with the 2015 pact, is under fire both at home and in Washington, which is weighing sanctions on him.
lead_paragraph: Iranian hard-liners have long mocked their foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, as the make-believe American, after a character in a comic Iranian movie who puts on an accent, wardrobe and lifestyle to live out a fantasy of American life.

headline: In His Own Words: Iran’s Foreign Minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a lengthy email exchange with the Times, he takes on his critics and muses about the future — for the nuclear deal and for himself.
lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian most closely associated with the 2015 nuclear agreement, has come under fire in Tehran and Washington as the deal approaches collapse. Hard-liners in Tehran accuse him of falling for false promises from the Americans. Trump administration officials call him a trickster who acts like a moderate while remaining steadfastly loyal to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader.

headline: Two Americas, Celebrating Separately in One Place
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Fireworks', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: On one side of the Mall, Fourth of July revelers listened to Carole King. On the other, they heard the president salute military might.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most days the National Mall, a two-mile grassy expanse with the Capitol on its east end and the Lincoln Memorial on the west, is home to Frisbee players, museumgoers and joggers. On the Fourth of July, it hosted two distinct versions of America.

headline: ‘Beats’ Review: In Chicago, the Song Remains the Same
abstract: A washed-up record producer finds hope in the talents of a traumatized young musician. But can he be trusted?
lead_paragraph: A veteran director of music videos for Jay-Z and Alicia Keys, Chris Robinson made his feature debut in 2006 with “ATL,” a coming-of-age story set in Atlanta, one of America’s great metropolitan music scenes. Although it takes place in Chicago, Robinson’s new Netflix movie, “Beats,” otherwise represents a return to familiar territory for the filmmaker, and too-familiar territory for the audience.

headline: Reflecting on the Border
abstract: This week on El Espace: A recap of the border crisis, a parent reflects on parenting her lighter skinned child and more.
lead_paragraph: El Espace is a column dedicated to news and culture relevant to Latinx communities. Expect politics, arts, analysis, personal essays and more. ¿Lo mejor? It’ll be in Spanish and English, so you can forward it to your tía, your primo Lalo or anyone else (read: everyone).

headline: Review: ‘Rock of Ages’ Returns, Scaled Down but Big Hair Intact
abstract: In a limited run Off Broadway, the jukebox musical about love and rocking out in the 1980s now includes songs by Def Leppard.
lead_paragraph: Are you ready to down Jell-O shots, headbang and play air drums, New York? Because “Rock of Ages” is back in town for a 10th-anniversary run, and it’s time to get happily stoopid.

headline: A Movement, and a Country, Torn by Protests
abstract: Hong Kong’s protests, which took a violent turn this week, threaten to divide the pro-democracy movement and bring on a backlash from Beijing.
lead_paragraph: When hundreds of thousands marched through the broiling streets of Hong Kong in recent weeks, they posed a serious challenge for the Chinese government. But when some of them stormed the Legislative Council and ransacked the chamber on Monday, they put their movement’s fragile gains at risk.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Hey, baby: It’s the Fourth of July. Maybe read a book about America? My father will be — ever the history student, he’s made it a life goal to collect books about each president. (He reminds me that a few years ago, when I gave him Candice Millard’s “Destiny of the Republic,” about James A. Garfield’s assassination, I told him, “Good luck finding a whole book on Rutherford B. Hayes.”)

headline: Wimbledon 2019: Serena Williams Escapes; Angelique Kerber Doesn’t
abstract: Williams needed three sets to get past a teenage qualifier. Kerber, the defending champion, lost to Lauren Davis, an unseeded American.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For a while, as the shadows marched slowly across Court No. 1 on Thursday, nothing worked for Serena Williams. Her vaunted serve crashed repeatedly into the net. Her groundstrokes careered wide or carried repeatedly long.

headline: 6.4-Magnitude Earthquake and Swarm of Aftershocks Rattle Southern California
abstract: Dozens of aftershocks rattled the same region after the big quake. But it appeared that no one was seriously injured.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A rolling 6.4-magnitude earthquake hit a remote area of Southern California between Los Angeles and Las Vegas on Thursday, the most powerful tremor to shake that region in two decades, according to the United States Geological Survey.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: June 28-July 4
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At least 264 pro-government forces and 58 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
lead_paragraph: At least 264 pro-government forces and 58 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week, the highest death toll of 2019. Attacks by the Taliban spiked around the country as American negotiators met with Taliban officials in the seventh round of peace talks in Doha. In Kabul, a complex Taliban attack including a car-bombing and militant assault killed at least 40 people, badly damaging a private war museum, an adjoining television station and a primary school, hurting dozens of children. In Kandahar, the Taliban launched coordinated attacks in Maruf District center, killing at least 45 security forces and eight election officials.

headline: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris Bring Their Debate-Stage Fight to Iowa
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The candidates continue to address questions about school integration, prolonging the most combative period of the Democratic primary to date.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa — Joseph R. Biden Jr. expressed frustration Thursday at Senator Kamala Harris’s pointed criticism about his 1970s-era opposition to busing, arguing that Democrats should “be talking about the future.” But he resisted the opportunity to return fire at Ms. Harris for voicing a position similar to his on school integration.

abstract: The second-round duel at Wimbledon had something often lacking in this golden era of men’s tennis: an edge.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The rematch was just about worth the five-year wait, as Nick Kyrgios and Rafael Nadal probed each other’s characters and explored the borders of their own talents in the second round of Wimbledon on Thursday.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Immigration Detention', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deportation']
abstract: Immigrants avoiding deportation by living in houses of worship received notices that they would be fined, the latest measure taken in an ongoing crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Edith Espinal spends her days praying, reading and, when feeling brave, taking short accompanied walks outside the Mennonite church in Columbus, Ohio, where she has been living for 21 months. Church leaders have been protecting Ms. Espinal, who crossed illegally into the United States more than two decades ago, while she fights a deportation order.

lead_paragraph: One of Norway’s most prominent politicians has been convicted of abusing his power to force three young men seeking asylum in the country to have sex with him.

headline: Venezuela Forces Killed Thousands, Then Covered It Up, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police', 'Torture', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Special forces members engaged in extrajudicial killings and then altered crime scenes to make it look as if the victims had been resisting arrest, United Nations investigators said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Venezuelan special forces have carried out thousands of extrajudicial killings in the past 18 months and then manipulated crime scenes to make it look as if the victims had been resisting arrest, the United Nations said on Thursday in a report detailing wide-ranging government abuses targeting political opponents.

headline: Mexico’s Federal Police Rebel Against New Security Plan
abstract: Mexico’s president created a new force to combat rising crime. The federal police are an important part of it. But officers are fighting the plan.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexican federal police officers are mutinying over the government’s decision to make them part of the country’s new National Guard, a powerful challenge to President Andrés Manuel López Obrador as he tries to fight rising crime.

headline: How to Straighten Out the Medicare Maze
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Expanding insurance coverage isn’t the only task ahead.
lead_paragraph: “Medicare for all” was a central theme in the initial Democratic debates and promises to be a defining issue in the primaries. While nearly all the candidates support expanded access, they should be pressed on another crucial question: How will they reduce the burdens involved in dealing with the interwoven public and private insurance systems that provide our health care coverage?

abstract: Sometimes patriotism is complicated.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Generation Z', 'Baby Boomers', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Social Media']
abstract: The revolt against Boomer morality.
lead_paragraph: There is some sort of hard-to-define spiritual crisis across the land, which shows up in rising depression rates, rising mental health problems. A survey that the Pew Research Center released late last year captures the mood. Pew asked people to describe the things that bring meaning to their lives. A shocking number of respondents described lives of quiet despair:

headline: Trump Is Losing His Trade Wars
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The pain is real, but the coercion isn’t.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s declaration that “trade wars are good, and easy to win” will surely go down in the history books as a classic utterance — but not in a good way. Instead it will go alongside Dick Cheney’s prediction, on the eve of the Iraq war, that “we will, in fact, be welcomed as liberators.” That is, it will be used to illustrate the arrogance and ignorance that so often drives crucial policy decisions.

headline: After 5,060 Straight Yankees Games, a Day Off for John Sterling
abstract: After pleas from friends and co-workers, the 81-year-old radio voice of the Yankees finally took a series off to maintain his health.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For the first day off from his job in 30 years, the man who broadcast every pitch thrown by Mariano Rivera and every inning played by Derek Jeter planned to enjoy waking up whenever he wanted. He also had a project to tackle at home: sorting through a pile of mail that he has ignored for a while.

headline: With Flyovers and Flags, Trump Plays M.C. for the Fourth
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Military Aircraft', 'Veterans', 'Parades', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The president began with a rare call for unity in his 45-minute speech, but mostly spent time recounting the history of the armed forces, planes punctuating his message.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a made-for-television Independence Day production starring America’s military weaponry, President Trump on Thursday used the Lincoln Memorial as the backdrop for a tribute to the country’s armed forces and a call for unity that has been largely absent during his divisive presidency.

headline: What to Cook When it’s Too Cold to Do Anything Else
abstract: We mix things up with an edition dedicated to food, including a selection of our favorite winter recipes from NYT Cooking.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by Tacey Rychter, a writer and audience editor with the Australia bureau.

headline: Sudan Power-Sharing Deal Reached by Military and Civilian Leaders
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The agreement promises an end to the standoff that has paralyzed the African country since the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir in April.
lead_paragraph: Sudan’s military and civilian leaders announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement to share power until elections, promising an end to the standoff that has paralyzed the African country since the ouster of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir in April.

headline: Sound Evidence
abstract: Freddie Cheng continues his quest to “hit for the cycle.”
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — “Hitting for the cycle,” or having at least one puzzle published for each day of the week, is not the be-all, end-all of puzzle making, but it certainly shows off a constructor’s chops. It also shows an ability to understand what the needs are for puzzles on each day of the week, with the aid of the editors.

headline: G.M. Leaves Lordstown Behind in Hard Bet on Future
abstract: General Motors’ survival may depend on transforming itself into more of a tech company at the expense of thousands of autoworkers.
lead_paragraph: With its focus on a future of self-driving cars and renewable fuels, General Motors is leaving some manufacturing plants like the one in Lordstown, Ohio, in its rearview. Workers who spent a lifetime at the plant — and constructed their lives around G.M. as they built the company’s cars — are losing their jobs. But this round of layoffs is different from the decades-old shifts in the auto industry. Competition from Silicon Valley, pressure from Wall Street and fundamental changes in how we get around are forcing the company to transform itself. It may be easy to say it’s not fair, but the American economy may not have room for fairness anymore.

headline: The House Where My Husband Doesn’t Exist
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Finally, I could be openly gay anywhere — except while visiting a certain relative.
lead_paragraph: I rang the doorbell of my grandmother’s house before remembering to pull off my wedding ring. I slipped it into my pocket and, just like that, I was someone else — an actor playing a fictional version of me.

headline: Chris Cline, Coal Mining Entrepreneur, Is Killed in Helicopter Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Coal', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: Mr. Cline was a well-known philanthropist and Republican donor who began working in the coal industry in West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Chris Cline, a billionaire entrepreneur, philanthropist and political donor once called the “King of Coal,” died Thursday in a helicopter crash in the Bahamas that officials said killed seven people.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Thoroughbreds’ and ‘Woman at War’
abstract: Olivia Cooke and Anya Taylor-Joy play teens with dark sides in “Thoroughbreds.” And Benedikt Erlingsson’s “Woman at War” hits Hulu.
lead_paragraph: THOROUGHBREDS (2018) 8:25 p.m. on HBO. “You ever think about just killing him?” That question is tossed out by Amanda (Olivia Cooke), an emotionally stunted high school student, in reference to her friend Lily’s stepfather in this debut from the writer-director Cory Finley. “How … would you?” Lily (Anya Taylor-Joy) replies, in a muted manner. Amanda and Lily are a pair of erstwhile friends brought back together by circumstance: The studious Lily is enlisted to tutor Amanda, whose troubled nature is bared at the beginning of the movie, when she kills her injured horse with a knife. This film is about their friendship, and their increasingly inability to reign in their darker sides. Though direct summation is difficult: “For all the chatter and intrigue,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times, Finley “never settles on a point or theme.” But, she wrote, the director “gives the movie a professional sheen and gets fine performances from his actors.”

headline: What to Watch Friday at Wimbledon
abstract: Cori Gauff looks to continue her run, and Andy Murray and Serena Williams team up in mixed doubles.
lead_paragraph: Halep, the winner of the 2018 French Open and a former world No. 1, hasn’t had the best year. For her, that means reaching only the round of 16 at the Australian Open and the quarterfinals at the French Open. On Centre Court for the third round of Wimbledon, she will face Azarenka, another former No. 1 and the winner of two Australian Open titles. Their last meeting was at Wimbledon in 2017 in the round of 16. Halep won in two sets, but through the first two rounds this year, Azarenka has looked like the better player, losing only 10 games.

headline: Elite Kid Justice: Are Privileged Teenagers More Likely to Get a Slap on the Wrist?
abstract: A Stanford swimmer convicted of sex assault. An elite student involved in “senior salute.” A claim of “affluenza.” The infuriating yet familiar cases setting off anger at the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: The outlines of the story were infuriating yet familiar: A young man of privilege was accused of a serious crime, arrested, prosecuted and then treated gently by a judge.

headline: It’s Not Just the White House in 2020. The Power to Draw Maps Is Also at Stake.
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: With the nation’s political maps hanging in the balance, Democrats are racing to win back statehouse chambers and Republicans are rushing to defend gains from 2010.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Only hours after the United States Supreme Court said it could do nothing to stop partisan gerrymandering of the nation’s political maps, Eric H. Holder Jr. had a message for his fellow Democrats in downtown Dallas.

headline: NATO Considers Missile Defense Upgrade, Risking Further Tensions With Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Treaties', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some alliance officials think the move is needed to counter Russia’s new cruise missiles, but it could be “a point of no return with the Russians,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — NATO military officials are exploring whether to upgrade their defenses to make them capable of shooting down newly deployed Russian intermediate-range nuclear missiles after a landmark arms treaty dissolves next month, according to three European officials.

headline: For Recording Her Boss’s Lewd Call, She, Not He, Will Go to Jail
abstract: An Indonesian school employee who recorded her boss making lewd comments must serve six months in prison for distributing indecent material, the Supreme Court ruled.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A school bookkeeper in Indonesia who recorded her boss’s lewd phone call as proof she was being harassed must serve at least six months in prison for distributing obscene material, the country’s Supreme Court has ruled.

headline: Former Rio Governor Describes Extensive Bribery in Bid for 2016 Olympics
abstract: Sergio Cabral, who is serving a 200-year prison sentence, testified that as many as nine International Olympic Committee members were paid off.
lead_paragraph: A former governor of Rio de Janeiro has made startling new allegations about the extent of a $2 million scheme to bribe sports officials in what became a successful effort to bring the Olympics to South America for the first time.

headline: Ralph Nader Begs to Differ, and So Do Two Authors
abstract: Letters to the Editor: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Ripples of My Mother’s Hunger
abstract: The hunger-shaped hole in my family’s history rotted into my full-blown eating disorder.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 16, my mother spent hours waiting in bread lines in communist Poland, biting at her nails. The year was 1972. The line was mostly women. Their bellies rattled with hunger, anticipation of food burning in their throats.

headline: Reflux Drugs Tied to Bone Fractures in Children
abstract: Infants are often given acid-suppressing medicines to treat gastroesophageal reflux, but the drugs may affect the bones.
lead_paragraph: Infants are sometimes treated for gastroesophageal reflux with acid-suppressing medicines, but a new study suggests that they may increase the risk for bone fracture later in childhood.

headline: A Lauded Satirist of the Weimar Republic Who Anticipated the Brutality of the Third Reich
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Kurt Tucholsky cloaked his despair over the rise of the Nazis in lighthearted satire. Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim explains.
lead_paragraph: “Germany is an anatomical oddity,” Kurt Tucholsky once wrote. “It writes with its left hand and acts with its right.” He would have known. As the most prominent columnist of the Weimar Republic, he skewered the fashions and follies of the newly ascendant right wing in reams of satirical essays, poems and cabaret songs under five different bylines. In his day, he was as famous as the kings of American late-night comedy are now — and just as powerless to affect elections.

headline: This Reporter Asks a Lot of Questions. In Japan, That Makes Her Unusual.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Isoko Mochizuki’s interrogations of government officials have made her something of a folk hero in Japan, where the press is known for being clubby and compliant.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Isoko Mochizuki, a reporter for Tokyo’s largest regional newspaper, walks into a government news conference pulling a burgundy wheeled suitcase that holds her laptop, books and notes. She sits toward the back. After the other journalists politely ask their questions, she pounces.

headline: The Roving, Kaleidoscopic Vision of Peter Orner
abstract: His latest collection of stories, “Maggie Brown & Others,” probes the fleeting connections of characters struggling to adjust to the rush of time.
lead_paragraph: MAGGIE BROWN & OTHERS By Peter Orner

headline: Strong Jobs Report Eases Fears of Damage From Trade War
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump declares that the economy is doing “unbelievably well” after payrolls grow by 224,000 in June.
lead_paragraph: A decade after the Great Recession released its grip on the American economy, the job market shows no sign of falling into another slump.

headline: In ‘Drill,’ Hito Steyerl Adds Polish to Images of a World Gone Mad
abstract: A new commission at the Park Avenue Armory confirms her unrivaled gaze on technology, politics and war.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Park Avenue Armory, the crenelated citadel that takes up an entire city block on the Upper East Side, are accustomed to seeing its cavernous Drill Hall retrofitted with bleachers and sales booths, dance floors, even tennis courts. But Hito Steyerl, the German artist and philosopher of our present technological debasement, has left the space largely empty, illuminated only by some lighting underfoot and three massive screens. In this inky vastness, you can remember that what’s now a palatial arts center was once meant for something else. The building we’re in is “quite literally a fortress,” an onscreen guide tells us, and beneath our feet is “a shooting gallery.”

headline: A ‘Daily’ Producer on How a ‘Crazy Idea’ Became a News Show for Millions
abstract: Theo Balcomb talks about the challenges of running such a popular podcast, the gray area it embraces and her early days in audio reporting.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center has started an interview series, Behind the Byline, to introduce you to Times journalists. Is there a reporter, photographer or editor whom you would like to get to know? Tell us in the form below.

headline: Why Stars Won’t Come to the Knicks
abstract: After winning just 17 games this season, the team targeted Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving in free agency. They signed with the Nets. This was part of a pattern.
lead_paragraph: For years it has seemed, at least in the view of New Yorkers, that  the opportunity to play in the greatest city in the world — and in Madison Square Garden, the world’s most famous arena — would be a powerful lure for the N.B.A.’s most talented players to sign with the Knicks.

headline: In Toronto, an Industrial Stretch Has Its Breakout Moment
abstract: Sterling Road is newly hip, thanks to the arrival of the Museum of Contemporary Art. But with its elevated profile, locals worry the old strip will lose its gritty magic.
lead_paragraph: Dismissed for decades as a postindustrial wasteland, Sterling Road, a zigzagging half-mile strip of old factories and warehouses, is getting a second life. Last summer, the North American debut of a splashy Banksy exhibition in an empty warehouse there drew a global spotlight. With the arrival of Toronto’s Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) last fall, Sterling Road is newly hip, its appeal broadening beyond the small cadre of tuned-in artists and bohemian types who for years have had it to themselves. The street’s cavernous structures have also quickly become hot real estate.

headline: ‘This Old House’ Turns 40
keywords: ['Television', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Do It Yourself']
abstract: The show’s three hosts contemplate how home renovation has evolved over the years.
lead_paragraph: While filming a 40th anniversary special for “This Old House” recently, Bob Vila, the show’s original host, stopped to consider why, after all these years, people still can’t seem to get enough of home improvement shows.

headline: Excavating a Horror That Some Koreans Wish Would Stay Buried
keywords: ['Korean War', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Vigilantes']
abstract: Park Sun-joo, a student of ancient human bones, is unearthing a more recent story: South Koreans killed by their own police and vigilantes during the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: ASAN, South Korea — On a lush hillside torn open by an excavator, Park Sun-joo and volunteers combed through the soil with trowels and brushes, looking for villagers, including children, who were bludgeoned and buried, some still alive and moaning, by their own neighbors in 1950, at the outset of the Korean War.

headline: The Curious Mystical Text Behind Marianne Williamson’s Presidential Bid
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Occult Sciences', 'Religion and Belief', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The New Age author was drawn to an esoteric bible in the 1970s. It  made her a self-help megastar. And now it has gone mainstream.
lead_paragraph: In the living room of an apartment near Wall Street last month, a group of supporters huddled around a large television watching as their candidate, Marianne Williamson, made her debut on the debate stage. The host pulled her hair nervously.

lead_paragraph: Joelle Lamberton, who grew up in East Calais, Vt., a tiny town north of Montpelier, learned to be comfortable with frigid temperatures, hard physical work, old houses and ghosts.

headline: The Founders Would Gag at Today’s Republicans
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The cult of Trump has embraced values and beliefs that Jefferson, Washington and Lincoln abhorred.
lead_paragraph: Kids in cages and tanks for the tyrant. After that dictator-friendly Fourth of July, it’s time for all true patriots to conduct a political gut check.

abstract: General Motors idled a factory in Lordstown, and hundreds of autoworkers lost their jobs. Did their politics change?

headline: Where Do You Turn When the Anti-Corruption Crusaders Are Dirty?
abstract: Brazil’s Operation Car Wash was supposed to overthrow the country’s culture of graft. Instead, it’s brought corruption into the heart of the state.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — On the surface, “Operation Car Wash” has been a virtuous crusade against political corruption in this country.

headline: What Middle-Class Families Want Politicians to Know
abstract: Leaders all want to help “everyday Americans.” But do they really understand what it takes?
lead_paragraph: Being middle class in America used to come with a certain amount of leisure and economic security. Today it involves an endless series of trade-offs and creative workarounds, career reinventions and an inescapable sense of dread.

headline: Tutankhamen Head Sells for $6 Million, Despite Protests from Egypt
abstract: Christie’s said the sale was legal. But Egypt’s government says the antiquity was looted and should be returned.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “It was smuggled. It belongs to Egypt,” said Magda Sakr, one of a dozen protesters gathered outside Christie’s auction house minutes before a stone head of the pharaoh Tutankhamen was set to be sold on Thursday night.

headline: Hong Kong Is a Work in Progress
keywords: ['Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Fugitives', 'Extradition', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The city’s unique arrangement with mainland China is worth protecting — even if it is harder to put into practice than anyone anticipated.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — July 1, the anniversary of the day that Hong Kong was reunified with mainland China in 1997, ought to be an occasion for celebration. It marks the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under the “one country, two systems” — the first such region in China. Yet on Monday, the date’s 22nd anniversary, guests received instructions to go to a confidential location before being ferried to the site of the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: The writer and director Ari Aster narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Florence Pugh.

headline: At Banks and Fund Firms, Access Is Too Often Denied, Blind and Deaf Investors Say
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Blindness', 'Deafness', 'Personal Finances', 'Retirement', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Braille', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Workers with sensory challenges face an array of digital obstacles to managing their retirement accounts and have sued to ensure banks’ websites comply with federal disability law.
lead_paragraph: Albert Rizzi gave up on trying to manage his nest egg because as a blind person, he encountered digital barriers constantly. Many of the websites, mobile apps, PDFs and software programs he needed were not accessible. Sometimes, they just didn’t work.

headline: How ‘Midsommar’ Takes a Bad Trip
abstract: The writer and director Ari Aster narrates a scene from his film, featuring Florence Pugh and some powerful mushroom tea.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Fendi, the Legacy of Empire — and Lagerfeld
abstract: The couture show at the Temple of Venus and Rome was a fitting homage to just how much the designer gave the house, and a step into an unknown future.
lead_paragraph: ROME — There has been some debate over how Karl Lagerfeld, former creative director of Chanel and Fendi, the man who essentially defined the role of the modern creative director until his death in February at age — well, no one is entirely sure; general guess is 85 — would have felt about the extravagant memorial held two weeks ago in Paris. He famously, after all, never wanted a grand public funeral. He hated looking back.

headline: On Politics: Trump’s Fourth of July
abstract: President Trump on Thursday used the Lincoln Memorial as the backdrop for a tribute to the country’s armed forces.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: On the Fourth of July, Melania Trump Dresses for Independence
abstract: But whose, exactly? Her own, or the country’s?
lead_paragraph: President Trump may have stymied some expectations with his we-are-all-one-nation speech after the military fashion show — sorry, display — in front of the Lincoln Memorial on the Fourth of July, but it was Melania Trump in a slouching-off-one-shoulder mid-calf Carolina Herrera dress, standing silent and smiling by his side in every picture, who really put a twist on the messaging.

headline: Amazon’s Deliveroo Investment Is Halted for U.K. Scrutiny
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A British regulator ordered that an Amazon-led cash infusion into the food-delivery start-up be paused to study whether it creates competition concerns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s competition regulator said on Friday that it had begun an investigation into a $575 million investment led by Amazon in the London-based food-delivery service Deliveroo, the latest effort by a government to potentially check the reach of a technology giant.

headline: Women Crash the Pool Party
abstract: The swimming pool scene, a symbol of summer and male desire, gets an infusion of female fantasy.
lead_paragraph: There is a three-second shot in Hulu’s “Shrill” that lingers. Annie, a tenderly insecure young journalist played by Aidy Bryant, is at her first Fat Babe Pool Party. It’s a glamorous bash featuring women dancing and splashing around in cute swimwear, and while Annie is enchanted with what she sees, she is not quite ready to experience it herself. Instead she perches on the pool’s edge in black jeans and a short-sleeve button-up shirt. In her journey toward self-acceptance, she is just getting her feet wet.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How Amar Stewart, Hip-Hop Painter and Cancer Survivor, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The Bushwick resident, who is devoted to healthy eating, spends much of his day in the art studio and with friends.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, the British-born painter Amar Stewart, who has portrayed hip-hop artists dressed as 17th-century aristocrats, battled Stage 4 skin cancer. He lost part of his tongue, 11 teeth and lymph nodes in the process. He’s had operations since then to be able to speak again, while continuing to work full time as a painter.

abstract: The technology giant predicted a 56 percent drop in quarterly operating profit, as the trade war between the United States and China caused havoc in the computer chip and smartphone markets.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s trade war with China has been felt around the world. The latest casualty: the South Korean electronics giant Samsung Electronics.

headline: Their Bodies Were Weapons: Dissident Photographers of the 1980s
abstract: A series of exhibitions at the Rencontres d’Arles photography festival shows how artists broke taboos about nudity, gender and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: ARLES, France — In communist Czechoslovakia, it paid to conform. But behind closed doors at Prague’s only gay club, people could be free.

lead_paragraph: The rapper ASAP Rocky has been detained in Stockholm for two weeks while investigations continue into an assault charge.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Accepting money from arms companies has long been unthinkable for most arts organizations in Europe. This year, taking money from the Sackler family, which has been linked to the opioid crisis, became taboo for many of them, too.

lead_paragraph: Even with a strong economy, a growing number of people are having trouble paying their credit card bills.

abstract: The departure of Garth Ritchie, head of the investment bank, is likely a first step in a broad bid by the bank to reverse its decline.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank said on Friday that the leader of its investment banking unit would resign, foreshadowing what are likely to be steep cuts in the bank’s operations in the United States and Europe.

abstract: Portraits of people forever tethered to the moon landing.

headline: Tsipras, Having Changed Greece, Now Seems Poised to Lose It
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: As elections approach Sunday, polls suggest the prime minister faces a stinging rejection from voters still hurting and angry after a decade of austerity.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — With elections approaching on Sunday, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has tried his best to remind frustrated Greeks how bad things were and how much better they had become during his four years in power.

headline: The Good News: The Job Market Is Solid. The Bad News: The Job Market Is Solid.
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Friday’s numbers take some of the immediate worries off the table, but they don’t mean that all is well in the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: The best news to be found in the June jobs numbers, released Friday morning, is in what they don’t show.

headline: How Sharon Tate’s Death and the Manson Killings Gripped Los Angeles
abstract: In August 1969, the actress Sharon Tate and four others were slain in a Beverly Hills home. Their gruesome deaths left the city reeling.
lead_paragraph: A maid called the police at 9 a.m. on Aug. 9, 1969, after finding five dead people in a Beverly Hills home. There was a blond woman on the living room floor, a rope wrapped around her neck and stab wounds in her swollen belly. A bloodied corpse wore a hood; another was behind the wheel of a car. Two more were sprawled on the lawn about 50 feet apart. A neighbor recalled hearing shots around midnight.

headline: What Denise Ho, Jackie Chan and Others Think About the Hong Kong Protests
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Music', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: Denise Ho, a Cantopop singer, has championed the protesters. But she is blacklisted in mainland China, and few Hong Kong stars have been willing to follow her lead.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As Hong Kong’s protests evolve into a struggle against the grip of authoritarian China, one of the city’s biggest pop stars has emerged as an icon of defiance. She has spoken at rallies, handed out voter registration forms at marches and stood on the front lines with demonstrators, urging the riot police not to charge.

headline: Make This Pie!
abstract: A blueberry lattice pie, brought to The Times by the late Molly O’Neill, is worth your time this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ll be on the road this weekend, driving north toward black flies and shooting stars. There’ll be yeasted doughnuts along the way, a lobster roll, an egg-and-white-cheese on an English muffin, a tub of poutine, ice-cold Cokes, lots of water, rinse and repeat into the depths of New England. I’ve got a three-ton jack in the back of the rig and plenty of tools if anything goes wrong, including a bucket for picking berries by the side of the interstate, should it come to it. Soundtrack? Jim Dale reading “Harry Potter,” which is very punk rock.

headline: FIFA President Proposes Expansion of Women’s World Cup and Doubling of Prize Money
abstract: Gianni Infantino will push to expand the women’s championship to 32 teams, perhaps as soon as 2023.
lead_paragraph: Basking in the success of this summer's Women’s World Cup in France, Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, said Friday that he had proposed expanding the event to 32 teams from 24, possibly as soon as the next World Cup in 2023, and doubling prize money and financial support for the teams that take part.

headline: Biden, in CNN Interview, Says Harris Caught Him Off Guard in Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Biden reiterated that Ms. Harris had mischaracterized his position on school busing, prolonging what has been a combative period of the presidential primary.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Friday that he had not been prepared for Senator Kamala Harris to so pointedly question his record on school busing during the first Democratic debates, extending the dispute between the two presidential candidates, who have sparred repeatedly in the week since their high-profile confrontation.

headline: Israel’s Energy Dilemma: More Natural Gas Than It Can Use or Export
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Solar Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: After years of relying on imports, the country has discovered huge gas reserves offshore. But it cannot easily use or sell the fuel to other countries.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — For decades, Israel was an energy-starved country surrounded by hostile, oil-rich neighbors.

headline: California Earthquake Is a Reminder That the Big One Lurks
abstract: The strongest of hundreds of aftershocks jolted Southern California on Friday morning, the day after a 6.4-magnitude earthquake was felt in Los Angeles and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For those near the epicenter of the earthquake that struck Southern California on Thursday, the ground jolted so violently that it bounced them off their feet.

headline: Kevin Spacey’s Accuser Drops Lawsuit
abstract: The young man who accused the actor of groping him withdrew his suit just six days after filing it. Mr. Spacey still faces a criminal charge.
lead_paragraph: The young man who accused Kevin Spacey of sexually assaulting him in a restaurant in Nantucket, Mass., in 2016 has dropped his lawsuit against the actor just six days after filing it.

headline: The Boys in the Band Get to Broadway. Why Not the Girls?
abstract: “The Prom” is the rare show with lesbian themes to reach theater’s biggest stage. Gay women deserve more than drawing their own conclusions about Princess Elsa and Scout Finch.
lead_paragraph: Recent Broadway revivals of “Angels in America,” “M. Butterfly,” “The Boys in the Band” and “Torch Song”— shows dealing with the gay experience — have attracted star power, awards and attention. Earlier this year, Tarell Alvin McCraney’s acclaimed Broadway debut, “Choir Boy,” focused on a charismatic gay youth who runs into trouble at his boarding school.

headline: Albariño Finds Its Inner Beauty
abstract: This Spanish wine rode the first wave of the new diversity. Now, producers are exploring its expressive potential.
lead_paragraph: Among the first wave of new grapes that came to define today’s era of diversity in wine was albariño, from the Rías Baixas region of Galicia in northwestern Spain.

headline: ‘Prospective Threat’ of Chinese Spying Justifies Huawei Ban, U.S. Says

keywords: ['Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: ‘Modern Slavery’ Ring in U.K. Ensnared up to 400 Polish People, Authorities Say
abstract: Eight traffickers from Poland have been convicted in what officials called the largest such case Britain has experienced.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They lived in desperate straits in Poland, often homeless and suffering from addictions. So when the call came to get free housing and well-paid jobs in Britain, hundreds decided to make the move.

headline: 4 Podcasts for Your Summer Travels
abstract: Laughs, learning, inspiration: These podcasts are by, for or about women (or all three). And, they’re great!
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines.

headline: The Sports Bra Seen Round the World Has New Meaning 20 Years Later
abstract: Brandi Chastain’s iconic World Cup celebration has come to illustrate a changing debate on how female athletes are depicted and treated.
lead_paragraph: Three days before the 1999 Women’s World Cup began, Brandi Chastain made an appearance on “Late Show With David Letterman.” Mia Hamm, the reluctant superstar, had declined, so Chastain went instead. Her nickname among teammates was Hollywood. It’s likely that few viewers knew who she was. But no one, we soon learned, was better prepared for bright lights and big moments.

headline: The Dominance of the White Male Critic
keywords: ['Culture (Arts)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Whites', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Whitney Biennial']
abstract: Conversations about our monuments, museums, screens and stages have the same blind spots as our political discourse.
lead_paragraph: “It’s 2019 and we are in the middle of a renaissance in black artistic production. And you are telling me the best people to evaluate that are the same ones who basically ignored black artists for decades?” the art critic Antwaun Sargent tweeted in May.

headline: 10 Great Rooftop Bars in New York City
abstract: Summer is a sweaty, trying season, but also the perfect time to enjoy a cold drink with a stunning view.
lead_paragraph: It’s not always easy to love New York City in the summer. The heat waves aren’t much of a reprieve from bitter winters and rainy springs. But it’s finally rooftop bar season, and there’s no better way to see the city skyline. You may have to wait in a line or two. Your drink is probably going to cost too much. But when you feel the breeze and watch the warm hues of golden hour wash over the buildings, you’ll remember why this is one of the most brilliant cities in the world. Here is a list to guide your way to the top.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Impostor,’ ‘The Waiter’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic is the No. 1 seed and the defending champion at Wimbledon, but in the first week of the tournament, his status as ATP Player Council president has been the bigger burden.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In his months on the campaign trail, Beto O’Rourke has wanted to make one thing explicitly clear: He is not a pendejo.

Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: A Trip to Another Latitude
abstract: Teranga’s airy room is one of the city’s loveliest spaces in which to graze, lounge and resist the levies of life.

headline: A Gentle Welcome to West Africa, at Teranga in East Harlem
abstract: You can build your own meal at this restaurant in the Africa Center, but it’s best to follow the chef Pierre Thiam’s lead.
lead_paragraph: A drape of waxy leaves, a drip of vines: You have arrived at another latitude. Palms lean protectively, ready to offer shade, but none is needed here indoors at Teranga in East Harlem, one of the city’s loveliest spaces in which to graze, lounge and resist the levies of life.

headline: Where Does Major American Art Come From? Mapping the Whitney Biennial.
abstract: We mapped 3,600 artists from nearly a century of Whitney Biennials.
lead_paragraph: We mapped 3,600 artists from nearly a century of Whitney Biennials.

headline: Make It Easy
abstract: Broiled salmon, one-pot spaghetti, mushroom shawarma pitas: These summer days call for meals that are simpler than simple.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, where we are always about simple cooking, but especially so this week. The holiday has passed, the days are getting hot, school is off, work is somehow still on — sometimes you just need dinner to be easier than easy, the culinary equivalent of screwing the cap off a bottle of white wine.

headline: New & Noteworthy Memoirs, From Prison to Boxing to Sexism
abstract: A selection of recent memoirs; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: ROUGHHOUSE FRIDAY: A Memoir, by Jaed Coffin. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) Coffin, who struggled with notions of manhood after his white father and Thai mother divorced, titles this lucid memoir after the barroom boxing matches he joined upon moving to Alaska.

headline: A Family’s Real-Life Lie and the Movie That Complicated It
abstract: When a cancer diagnosis was kept secret from her grandmother, Lulu Wang knew she had a film. But how to explain her project to a matriarch who’s still in the dark?
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In 2013, the director Lulu Wang was told that her grandmother had   Stage 4 lung cancer and had three months to live. The family had decided not to tell the matriarch of the diagnosis, believing that no good could come of it, and devised an elaborate ruse — a wedding banquet, in her hometown Changchun — as an excuse for everyone to go to China to see her one last time.

headline: Have Dog, Will Write
abstract: You might be surprised to learn how many authors on the current best-seller lists have had help — well, sort of — from their dogs.
lead_paragraph: You might be surprised to learn how many authors on the current best-seller lists have had help — well, sort of — from their dogs. (Note to cat people: Please don’t be offended. We’ll investigate writers and their felines another week.)

headline: ‘Eight’ Is a Breakthrough for Virtual Reality in Classical Music

So far, orchestras and opera houses have come up with little more than 360-degree videos that show concerts from the perspective of the conductor’s podium.

headline: For No-Sweat Summer Cooking, Do It Sous Vide
abstract: Used along with a grill, the sous-vide machine guarantees flavorful steaks, fish and vegetables done with predictability and precision.
lead_paragraph: Jake Springfield considers himself a pretty average home cook. A New Orleans cinematographer who works on commercials, he’s not the kind of guy who dabbles in homemade charcuterie or cultivates his own sourdough starter. He isn’t inclined to cook offal, and he has never even fermented a pickle.

headline: A Writer of Three Women’s Sex Lives Shares Her Own Journey

lead_paragraph: Picture a 23-year-old woman dancing on a table in a Manhattan bar on, say, a Thursday night. Around 11 p.m., she says her goodbyes and rushes to Penn Station, so she can make the 11:38 p.m. train to Short Hills, N.J., where she is living with her Italian mother, who doesn’t know how to drive or write checks.

lead_paragraph: While it hardly qualified me as a wilderness expert, my time as a Cub Scout and Boy Scout at least gave me a general idea of what camping is all about. But even that kind of familiarity is not something many, if not most, immigrants possess when they arrive in this land of lakes, forests and campgrounds.

headline: Sweet, Sour and Ready to Top Toast
abstract: Caponata swaps eggplant for zucchini and summer squash in this easy picnic-ready recipe.
lead_paragraph: My introduction to caponata, when I was a teenager, was a supermarket version from a shelf somewhere near the tinned sardines and anchovies. It came in a distinctive disc-shaped glass jar, about 4 inches in diameter and an inch deep. The clamped-on lid was imprinted with an ornate logo, and somewhere it said “product of Italy.”

headline: Sid Ramin, ‘West Side Story’ Orchestrator and a Composer, Dies at 100
abstract: A childhood friend of Leonard Bernstein, he won an Oscar and a Grammy for his work on the film “West Side Story” and 12 Clio Awards for his work in TV advertising.
lead_paragraph: Sid Ramin, an orchestrator, arranger and composer who won both an Oscar and a Grammy for his work on the film “West Side Story” and whose career outlets ranged from revered Broadway musicals to perfume commercials, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 100.

headline: Barry Kowalski, Prosecutor in Rodney King Case, Is Dead at 74
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Legal Profession', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: “He’s been called the Justice Department’s pit bull,” a colleague said of Mr. Kowalski, who prosecuted many high-profile civil rights cases.
lead_paragraph: Barry F. Kowalski, a Justice Department lawyer who prosecuted high-profile civil rights cases, most notably winning the convictions of two white Los Angeles police officers in 1993 for the beating of Rodney G. King — an episode that touched off one of the nation’s worst urban riots — died on Sunday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 74.

headline: Restoring Forests Could Help Put a Brake on Global Warming, Study Finds
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Environment']
abstract: Researchers looked at how many trees could be planted on every available parcel of land on Earth, where they could go, and what impact could be on our survival.
lead_paragraph: What if we stopped cutting down forests to produce palm oil and cattle? What if we grew new forests on vacant city lots, old industrial buildings — even golf courses?

headline: What Do You Get When You Cross Mark Morris With Samuel Beckett?
abstract: The choreographer, whose playfulness is serious, will stage three pieces by Beckett, who wears his seriousness lightly, at a festival in Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A large portrait of Samuel Beckett — peaked hair, deeply furrowed brow, piercing blue eyes — looms over the public area of the Palace Bar, an 1823 watering hole long loved by journalists and writers. At midday, the bar was all dark wood and filtered light, muttering male voices, and the faint whoosh of glasses filling with beer.

headline: E.U.’s Top Pick: Too Pious for Feminists, Too Feminist for Conservatives

headline: Mickey Kapp, Who Made Mixtapes for Astronauts, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Kapp, a record producer, became the unofficial music provider to the space-bound after forging an unlikely connection with members of the Mercury 7 crew.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Kapp, a record producer who, after forging a somewhat improbable connection with several Mercury 7 astronauts, went on to provide later space explorers with customized mixtapes to listen to during their historic flights, died on June 11 at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 88.

headline: In Sudan, a Power-Sharing Deal Propelled by a Secret Meeting and Public Rage
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Just a month ago, Sudan’s protest movement appeared crippled. What led the military to suddenly agree to share power? Back-room negotiations, raw street power and a diplomatic shift by Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: A month ago Sudan’s pro-democracy movement was battered and in disarray. Protesters were in hiding after paramilitary troops rampaged through the main protest area, looting, raping and shooting dead scores of people. The internet had been shut down. Bodies were being dredged from the Nile.

headline: Tunisia Bans Full-Face Veils for Security Reasons
abstract: The decision came amid a growing effort to fight terrorism, and met with little public criticism. “Society is aware of the necessity of security,” an academic said.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS, Tunisia — Prime Minister Youssef Chahed of Tunisia on Friday prohibited anyone wearing the niqab, a religious covering for the face with only an opening for the eyes, from entering public institutions and government offices, citing security reasons.

headline: Corrections: July 6, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, July 6, 2019.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS

headline: Walletful
abstract: Erik Agard on a Saturday? Take the money and run.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE  — They grow up so fast. Don’t they? I have gotten used to feeling like a wacky great-aunt trying to keep up with the youngs, like Erik Agard and his brilliant constructor cohort of 20-somethings (and some teenagers). But then we get a grid like today’s, with sedate references to vinyl, tea, “Wheel of Fortune,” Michael DUKAKIS, law, religion and finance terms, and PABLO CASALS. Now I’m marveling at the guy’s refinement and maturity.

headline: Southern California Rocked by Earthquake for Second Time in Two Days
abstract: Seismologists warn that the 7.1-magnitude quake will likely be followed by more seismic activity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A 7.1-magnitude earthquake rattled Southern California on Friday night, one day after the strongest recorded quake there in 20 years had struck — and seismologists warned that further episodes are expected.

headline: What to Watch Saturday at Wimbledon
abstract: Rafael Nadal, Roger Federer and a double dose of Serena Williams and Andy Murray are on the docket.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ and ‘Enchanted Kingdom’
abstract: Rami Malek struts his stuff as Freddie Mercury, and Idris Elba narrates an immersive wildlife documentary about Africa.
lead_paragraph: BOHEMIAN RHAPSODY (2018) Stream on HBO platforms. Few songs are as evocative of an American summer as those of Queen, whether you’re stomping along to “We Will Rock You” at a baseball game or belting out “Don’t Stop Me Now” at a backyard barbecue. Sure, Freddie Mercury and his bandmates were from England, but Queen’s music continues to reverberate across American culture, a phenomenon this Academy Award-winning biopic explores. Rami Malek (wearing a convincing set of prosthetic teeth) plays the Queen frontman in the film, which charts the band’s dazzling rise and experimental songwriting, alongside some of Mercury’s personal struggles. Although Malek’s performance earned him an Oscar for best actor, the New York Times critic A.O. Scott wrote that the film doesn’t do enough to capture “the glorious and unlikely artifice of Queen itself, a band whose scrambling of sexual and musical codes remains a remarkable phenomenon in the history of popular culture.”

headline: Gucci Goes for Gold (and Diamonds, Too)
abstract: The Italian fashion house shows its first high jewelry collection during the couture in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Gucci’s much-touted inclusivity is not limited to community: It extends to products, too. There is little, it seems, that the brand and its creative director, Alessandro Michele, do not see as potential parts of their magic magpie mash-up vision, from sneakers to china and, as of this past week, haute jewelry, that top-end intersection of rare gems and elevated workmanship.

headline: The Week in Arts: The Music of Birdsong, Captives Onstage and a Poet in Love
abstract: Sculpture by Carmen Herrera, a retooled Belle & Sebastian and Leonard Cohen’s real Marianne.
