headline: Taiwan President Risks Infuriating China With U.S. Visit
abstract: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan, which China considers a breakaway province, visits the United States and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Taiwan, the self-governing island of 24 million claimed by China, visited the United States on Thursday and said her people would “never be intimidated,” risking China’s wrath and a further fraying of ties between Beijing and the Trump administration.

headline: Francine Shapiro, Developer of Eye-Movement Therapy, Dies at 71
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Dr. Shapiro’s technique for dealing with trauma was initially met with some skepticism. But it has attracted devotees worldwide.
lead_paragraph: One spring afternoon in 1987, a psychology student trying to shake off an upsetting memory took a stroll through a park in Los Gatos, Calif., distracting herself by darting her eyes back and forth. The sting of the memory quickly faded, and the student, Francine Shapiro, glimpsed her future.

headline: Is This the End of Anonymous Shell Companies? Not Too Fast
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Tax Shelters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporations', 'States (US)', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: The use of L.L.C.s and shell corporations to hide the true source of funds has been an issue for the United States for more than a decade. A bill in Congress seeks to address it.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: What Leonardo da Vinci Couldn’t Finish
abstract: “Saint Jerome Praying in the Wilderness” at the Met Museum is a masterpiece in progress from a perfectionist who hated to say “done.”
lead_paragraph: The 500th anniversary of the death of Leonardo da Vinci will bring big doings to Paris this fall with the largest-ever and one-stop-only career survey at the Louvre. And New York gets a shot of buzz in advance with the opening at the Met on July 15 of a single-painting show of one of the most rawly emotional images in the Leonardo canon.

headline: Madame Mela, Tu Astróloga Favorita
abstract: This week on El Espace: Stories on the importance of having critics of color, the African roots of Dominican music and more.
lead_paragraph: El Espace is a column dedicated to news and culture relevant to Latinx communities. Expect politics, arts, analysis, personal essays and more. ¿Lo mejor? It’ll be in Spanish and English, so you can forward it to your tía, your primo Lalo or anyone else (read: everyone).

headline: California Lawmakers Give Utilities a Backstop on Wildfire Liability
abstract: Legislators moved to create a fund to help cover claims from blazes caused by the companies’ equipment. The bill aimed to shore up investor confidence.
lead_paragraph: Heading into another wildfire season, California’s political leaders have moved with unusual speed to help the state’s utilities erect a backstop against huge liability claims.

headline: Andrew Dibner, Medical Alert Pioneer, Is Dead at 93
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Elderly', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Concerned about what happens when people fall and can’t reach a telephone to call an ambulance, Mr. Dibner, a psychologist, developed a system to help.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Dibner, a psychologist who created a new segment in the health care industry when he invented a medical alert system that let elderly and disabled people call for help when they cannot reach a telephone or knock on a neighbor’s door, died on Saturday in a memory care facility in Peoria, Ariz. He was 93.

headline: Review: ‘The Little Prince’ Travels the Universe but Never Lifts Off

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Anna Tatishvili’s tennis comeback looked merciless even before she took the court last month. After losing 19 months of her career to a persistent ankle injury, she returned at the French Open and learned that she had drawn an opponent nobody wanted to face in the first round: the No. 29 seed, Maria Sakkari, who led the women’s tour with 12 clay-court wins heading into the tournament.

headline: Jim Bouton Opened Up the Major Leagues to Everyone

lead_paragraph: In high school they called him Warm-Up, because he only ever pitched in the bullpen. He was an unknown, this Jim Bouton, having just moved to Illinois from New Jersey. He loved the game, sure. But that didn’t mean they had to let him pitch.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, the song of the summer for me was Jason Isbell’s sweet-sad “If We Were Vampires,” with its perfect blend of romance and mortality: “It’s knowing that this can’t go on forever / Likely one of us will have to spend some days alone.” (That line becomes next-level excellent when you realize that the haunting backup vocals are provided by Isbell’s wife, Amanda Shires.) This summer, I’m getting a similarly poignant shiver from the novella “Walt Kaplan Is Broke,” which closes Peter Orner’s terrific new story collection “Maggie Brown & Others” and features a coronary patient taking stock of his long, mostly happy marriage: “I’m afraid of dying because I love my wife.” There’s a lot of affection in that story, and in all of Orner’s characteristically generous work, and you could do worse than settling in with his book this week.

It was also underfunded, which is why deductibles are often uncomfortably high. And the law has faced sabotage both from G.O.P.-controlled state governments and, since 2017, the Trump administration.

Her only wish now, Fatima said, was to be with her daughter again.

headline: Forty-Niners’ Equipment

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If life was logical, the difficulty levels of crossword puzzles would get easier as the week goes on. We would start out the week with a real brain twister — sort of a multivitamin for the brain — to rev up our engines and get us primed for the week ahead. Then, after a long, busy week, we would put our feet up and solve a smooth, straightforward crossword to boost our self-confidence and let us know that, despite what might be going on in other parts of our messy lives, we succeeded in putting at least one thing in order.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Shangri-La’ and Two Denzel Washington Movies
abstract: A four-part documentary about the record producer Rick Rubin begins. And Denzel Washington occupies both sides of the moral coin (or subway token).
lead_paragraph: SHANGRI-LA 9 p.m. on Showtime. The fabled Shangri-La recording studio in Malibu, Calif., was once a hangout for the Band and Bob Dylan. Now, it’s an oasis overseen by the megaproducer Rick Rubin — and a reflection of Rubin’s minimalist sensibilities. So it makes sense as a setting for this four-part documentary from the director Morgan Neville (“Won’t You Be My Neighbor?”), which takes a meandering dive into Rubin’s life and work as a producer. The fact that Rubin has worked across so many genres (his best-known collaborations include producing for acts like the Beastie Boys and Johnny Cash) means that this dive should have something for everyone. But as the title suggests, the star may be the studio itself. “There’s an extra, added feeling of coming to a place where a lot of good music has been made,” Rubin says in the first episode. “I don’t know if it’s the energy collected in the space, or if it’s just people’s belief,” he adds. “It doesn’t really matter.”

headline: Who Mows the Lawn at Storm King, New York’s Largest Sculpture Park?
abstract: It takes a crew of eight to maintain the 500 acres at Storm King Art Center, where art lives in the landscape.
lead_paragraph: Storm King Art Center isn’t a museum, exactly. Instead of hanging on white walls or resting on pedestals under track lighting, the art here is nestled amid 500 acres of verdant hills, exposed to the ever-shifting and unrelenting climate of New York’s Hudson Valley.

headline: Turkey Gets Shipment of Russian Missile System, Defying U.S.
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The purchase of the sophisticated S-400 antiaircraft equipment was fiercely opposed by NATO and by Washington, which is expected to respond with sanctions.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Defying strenuous American objections and the threat of sanctions, Turkey began receiving the first shipment of a sophisticated Russian surface-to-air missile system on Friday, a step certain to test the country’s uneasy place in the NATO alliance.

headline: Duduzane Zuma, Son of South Africa’s Ex-President, Is Acquitted in Homicide Case
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The son of Jacob Zuma faced charges for his role in a deadly 2014 collision in which his Porsche 911 crashed into a minibus in Johannesburg.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A politically influential son of former President Jacob Zuma of South Africa was cleared of culpable homicide on Friday in a case that has come to be seen as a proxy for factional battles within the governing African National Congress.

headline: When Our Daughter Walked In on Us
keywords: ['Sex', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Families and Family Life', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Menopause']
abstract: If only we had been under the covers like normal parents.
lead_paragraph: One sunny Sunday morning, my husband and I were in bed, right in the middle of things, when he shouted and pulled the comforter over us. But it was too late: We’d been caught.

headline: Beware the Writer as Houseguest
abstract: Literary history is filled with authors who depended on lengthy visits for room and board, psychological solace and material. But they have not always proved the most gracious guests.
lead_paragraph: Consider the writer as houseguest. Is it a good idea to invite someone into your home whose occupation it is to observe everything? The writer as host might be no better. Even the most thoughtful guest will undoubtedly interfere with the writer’s productivity during the visit. It’s really no surprise that people who write for a living have given us some of our wisest sayings about a visit’s proper length.

headline: The Dress Code at Goop May Not Surprise You
abstract: The boss sets the fashion at Goop’s new light-filled headquarters in California.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — “I’m buying that shirt,” the publicist said to her boss. It was an everyday office compliment, except the boss in question was Gwyneth Paltrow (“G.P.,” as she’s known at the office), the founder and lifestyle guru behind Goop, which sells crystals, cashmere and much more.

headline: Move Over, Therapy Dogs. Hello, Therapy Cows.
keywords: ['Cattle', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: The best therapists for silly human problems don’t say a word.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, N.Y. — Even without a psychology degree, Bella’s natural talents made her an excellent therapist: She is calm and accommodating of a range of personalities, with the patience to listen to endless problems without so much as a judgmental moo.

headline: A Novel About Women’s Solidarity That Nods at ‘Magic Marker Terrorists’

headline: The Long History of the U.S. Government Asking Americans Whether They Are Citizens
keywords: ['Population', 'Census', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Some form of the question has been asked by the Census Bureau for decades, as the Trump administration has said. But what was asked of whom, and why, has varied widely.
lead_paragraph: When Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross ordered the Census Bureau to attach a question on citizenship to the 2020 census, the first argument he used to back up his decision was also the simplest: We’ve always asked. The question has been “a longstanding historical practice,” he wrote, “asked in some form or another for nearly 200 years.”

headline: Tropical Storm Barry Nears Louisiana City That Eluded Recent Hurricanes
abstract: Morgan City, a city of 12,000 people, may be the landing point for Tropical Storm Barry, which is predicted to turn into a Category 1 hurricane.
lead_paragraph: Morgan City’s motto is “Right in the Middle of Everywhere.” On Saturday morning, the Louisiana city of 12,000 people may find itself right in the middle of a hurricane.

headline: How Federer Beat Nadal to Advance to the Wimbledon Final
abstract: Roger Federer won, 7-6 (3), 1-6, 6-3, 6-4, and will face Novak Djokovic in the final on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Unlike Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal’s duel into the twilight on Centre Court in 2008, their match Friday was not a contender for the greatest match of all time.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Lake Success,’ ‘Bring the War Home’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Lake Success, by Gary Shteyngart. (Random House, $18.) Overwhelmed by his young son’s autism diagnosis and dodging a subpoena from the S.E.C., this book’s antihero leaves behind a job at a Manhattan hedge fund and hops on a Greyhound bus, hoping to reconnect with an ex-girlfriend teaching Holocaust studies in El Paso. Shteyngart’s frantic humor keeps the story afloat and gleefully satirizes the upper class.

headline: Rewriting Greek Tragedies as Immigrant Stories
abstract: Luis Alfaro, whose latest play is an adaptation of “Medea,” appreciates such “primal” points of origin: “They get to the essence: why we hurt each other, this inability to forgive.”
lead_paragraph: Luis Alfaro didn’t expect to find the heroine of a Greek tragedy at a juvenile hall in Tucson, Ariz.

headline: New York Was Supposedly Getting Better for Cyclists. What Happened?
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: As the city makes way for more bike paths, there is also more congestion than ever, and cyclist fatalities are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: On a particularly humid evening this week, hundreds of cyclists gathered in Washington Square Park for an action reminiscent of the years when AIDS summoned so many to protest bureaucratic indifference to tragedy. After several speeches addressing the need for cyclists to be better protected on the road, those who came to the park staged a die-in, lying down in mournful silence — a response to what has become known in the biking community as “the crisis.”

headline: American Commandos Gear Up for New Shadow War With Russia
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Even as President Trump courts Russia, Special Operations forces are teaming up with partners on Europe’s eastern flank to counter a mix of subterfuge, cyberattacks and disinformation.
lead_paragraph: SZOLNOK, Hungary — Secretive, behind-the-lines mission rehearsals and other operations by 1,400 American and allied commandos to combat shifting Russian threats have laid bare a fundamental tension in the Trump administration: While the president courts Moscow, much of his government considers it an increasingly dangerous foe.

headline: A Balkans Cycling Trip: Great Scenery! Ice-Cold Beer! And Bats and Land Mines?
abstract: Five friends jumped on bikes for a 100-mile trip from Bosnia to Croatia. The ride was challenging, and they laughed off the surprises.
lead_paragraph: My four friends and I rolled our bikes to a bar one sunny afternoon near the town of Zitomislici on the banks of the emerald green Neretva River in rural Bosnia. We stopped at Neretvansky Gusar, as the bar is called, to restock our water supply. There was only one problem: “I only have ice-cold beer,” apologized the longhaired proprietor, Nikola Bevanda, who prefers the nickname “Svabo,” slang for “The German.”

headline: The 2008 Crash Made This Madrid Suburb a Ghost Town. Now It’s Coming Alive.
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Education (K-12)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building (Construction)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Valdeluz, created as a commuter haven, is emerging from a lost decade after the financial crisis. But its former dreams, like a 1,500-student school, remain out of reach.
lead_paragraph: In Valdeluz, a town outside Madrid that was envisioned as a commuter’s paradise when it was created 15 years ago, there was always supposed to be a school. And a private one, for kindergartners to high schoolers, opened in September 2007 — just a year before the global financial crisis burst Spain’s property bubble.

headline: Turning New York Green
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: The ambitious plan to fight climate change in New York will have an outsize effect on housing here.
lead_paragraph: The ambitious plan to fight climate change in New York will have an outsize effect on housing here.

headline: Counting Down to a Green New York
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Solar Energy', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Sustainable Living', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Affordable Housing', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: New York plans to be carbon neutral by 2050, and housing is one of the biggest polluters. Can this dirty old town clean up its act in time?
lead_paragraph: New York’s ambitious plan to fight climate change by virtually eliminating greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 is underway — and the battle begins at home.

headline: Facebook’s Digital Money Could Mean Fabulous Wealth. Or Not.
abstract: The social network is planning a new cryptocurrency, potentially inserting the company into yet another part of our lives. Our reporter wonders: What’s in it for me?
lead_paragraph: Jack Ma, a co-founder of Alibaba,  was recently asked about the secret of his success. “I know nothing about technology,” he said. “I know nothing about marketing.” He said what he knows about is people. A successful business, he said, is all about making people happy.

headline: Where Are All the Bob Ross Paintings? We Found Them.
abstract: Bob Ross painted more than 1,000 landscapes for his television show — so why are they so hard to find? We solve one of the internet’s favorite little mysteries.
lead_paragraph: Bob Ross made three versions of each painting that appeared on “The Joy of Painting.” The first was made before the show, to be used as a reference. He painted the second during the 26-minute taping, sometimes with last-minute improvisations. The third was made afterward, for instructional books.

headline: Buying Lattes Is Not Keeping You From Being Rich
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Savings', 'Government Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Certificates of Deposit', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Mutual Funds', 'Books and Literature', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Have as many lattes as you want. Just make sure you focus on the handful of things that will make a major difference to your financial health, a financial adviser says.
lead_paragraph: “I Will Teach You to Be Rich” didn’t get as much attention as it deserved when it was first published a decade ago, and it’s easy to understand why.

headline: Trump’s Cruelty and Mexico’s Duty
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Aid', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There’s a right way and a wrong way to deal with the immigration crisis. Guess which the American president is choosing.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Here in Mexico, as around the world, we are haunted by the wrenching image of Óscar Alberto Martínez Ramírez, 25, and his 23-month-old daughter, Valeria, nestled together on the bank of the Rio Grande after they drowned in the river near the international bridge to Texas. This tragedy shines an unforgiving light on the President Trump’s crackdown on legal asylum claims at the border.

headline: It Was Never About Busing
keywords: ['Segregation and Desegregation', 'Education (K-12)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Whites', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Court-ordered desegregation worked. But white racism made it hard to accept.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Kamala Harris confronted former Vice President Joe Biden at the second Democratic presidential debate about his support of bills to ban busing for school desegregation during the 1970s and early ’80s, he gave a sort of denial. “I did not oppose busing in America,” he said. “What I opposed is busing ordered by the Department of Education. That’s what I opposed.”

abstract: Aquinas Kasbar, 19, faces up to a year in prison for stealing Isaac, who Santa Ana Zoo officials say is the oldest ring-tailed lemur in captivity in North America.
lead_paragraph: It was a case worthy of Ace Ventura, the pet detective.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: A deal announced Friday is an example of how carmakers are joining forces to survive a major shift in technology. But can two longtime rivals cooperate?
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor and Volkswagen said Friday that they would team up to develop self-driving cars and share electric-car components. The move broadens an existing alliance and shows how automakers are putting aside rivalries to manage the cost of new technologies.

keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Art', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Software', 'Computer Chips']

lead_paragraph: Video gaming has gone from an activity conducted in arcades, dens and rec rooms to a mobile phenomenon where players meet, live and play in virtual space.

headline: How a Tax Loophole Is Helping Silicon Valley Workers Save Millions
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Small Business', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: A little-known tax break allows some start-up employees who own company stock to avoid paying taxes on up to $10 million when they sell their shares.
lead_paragraph: When Kay Luo joined LinkedIn in 2006, she received a grant of shares with a value of 12 cents each. The company went public in 2011 at $45 a share. By the end of the first day of trading, the price had doubled, and she began the process of selling her stock.

headline: Acosta to Resign as Labor Secretary Over Jeffrey Epstein Plea Deal
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Prostitution', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: President Trump said the decision to resign was made by his labor secretary, R. Alexander Acosta.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s embattled labor secretary, R. Alexander Acosta, announced his resignation on Friday amid continuing questions about his handling of a sex crimes case involving the financier Jeffrey Epstein when Mr. Acosta was a federal prosecutor in Florida.

headline: Gina Torres on ‘Suits,’ Meghan Markle and ‘Pearson’
abstract: She’s bringing Jessica Pearson out of retirement to star in a new political drama as a fixer in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: In September 2016, after departing “Suits” as its legal queen bee, Jessica Pearson, Gina Torres spoke about leaving a door open. But walking back through it, she now admits, was the furthest thing from her mind.

headline: Bare Skin Is the Canvas for Donna Huanca
abstract: For her first big museum show in the United States, Ms. Huanca updates the tradition of body art.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the first time in its history, the recessed, ground-floor gallery at the Marciano Art Foundation looked like the backstage of a women’s fashion show. A clothing rack held odd garments and hair extensions, a model sat having her makeup touched up, and others shuffled around in white robes.

headline: What to Do in New York This Weekend
abstract: From poetic and political imagery in the Bronx to dancers swimming and playing tennis onstage at Lincoln Center, here’s a guide to some of what’s on offer around the city.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Documentary Center’s second annual Latin American Foto Festival is highlighting the work of 10 photographers from eight Spanish-speaking countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. “Most of the artists are working on intimate stories about social issues using innovative visual approaches that stretch the boundaries of traditional documentary photography,” James Estrin wrote in his feature about the festival, which also includes panel discussions and workshops. Through July 21; bronxdoc.org.

headline: Sports: Serena Chases a Grand Slam Record at Wimbledon
abstract: This is the third Grand Slam final for Serena Williams since she gave birth to her daughter. She lost the first two — can she win Saturday at Wimbledon?
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams reaching the Wimbledon final, where she’ll face Simona Halep on Saturday, is momentous on several fronts:

headline: This Is the Tart of the Summer
abstract: Dorie Greenspan is back, and she brought us a strawberry tart.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan’s back! She’s been off skylarking around Paris, working on books, being fantastic, but now she’s returned to the pages of The Times with a perfect recipe for your weekend kitchen workshop, a tumbly-jumbly strawberry tart (above). As she wrote in a column for us, it’s a treat she’s been making every summer, all summer, for roughly the past 15 years. Now it can be yours.

headline: 9 Places to Enjoy a Delicious Brunch in New York City
abstract: However you feel about the midday meal, you should know a few great spots to get one.
lead_paragraph: The only thing worse than a lackluster brunch is a practiced, performed public hatred of it. No one should wait an hour on line for overcooked eggs, but brunch can be better than fine. And in New York, joining in may be unavoidable. Whatever your feelings about the meal, it pays to have a list of commendable brunch restaurants in your back pocket.

headline: Behind the Scenes in the Food Biz: Four Culinary Memoirs
abstract: It’s hardly glamorous but still enticing, as reported by a young black chef, an obsessive blogger, a prickly female restaurateur and the man who made Noma famous.
lead_paragraph: NOTES FROM A YOUNG BLACK CHEF A Memoir By Kwame Onwuachi with Joshua David Stein

headline: Gay and Once Divorced, a Canadian Rabbi Broadens Judaism’s Tent
keywords: ['Rabbis', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Rabbi Lisa Grushcow, a Rhodes scholar who leads a Montreal synagogue, has won over many skeptics. Even a local Orthodox rabbi said, “Rabbi Grushcow is my rabbi.”
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — When Rabbi Lisa Grushcow, the first openly gay rabbi of a large synagogue in Canada, was preparing to begin rabbinical school, she faced a daunting choice: love or serving God.

headline: Government Could Breach Debt Ceiling in September, Mnuchin Warns
abstract: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warned Congress that the government could breach its statutory borrowing limit by September, begging for a debt ceiling increase.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin informed congressional leaders on Friday that the government could run out of money in early September, pleading with lawmakers to reach a deal to raise the government’s borrowing limit before their August recess or risk a potentially catastrophic default.

headline: A Burning Lava Lake Concealed by a Volcano’s Glacial Ice
abstract: Persistent pools of lava are quite rare on Earth, and it took years of satellite images to find this one.
lead_paragraph: While Earth’s surface is peppered with volcanoes, lava lakes appear to be vanishingly rare. Popular imagery of volcanoes may imply that these crowning caldrons of liquid fire are common, but there were thought to be only seven contemporary volcanoes on Earth with persistent lava lakes that have been seen to stick around beyond a single eruptive outburst.

headline: Acosta Resigned. The Caligula Administration Lives On.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Domestic Violence', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The Epstein case is a reminder of the depraved milieu from which our president sprang.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Donald Trump disinvited the then-British ambassador, Kim Darroch, from an official administration dinner with the emir of Qatar, because he was mad about leaked cables in which Darroch assessed the president as “insecure” and “incompetent.”

headline: Rene Favaloro, a Pioneering Surgeon, Is Honored in Today’s Google Doodle
abstract: Dr. Favaloro, a leader in heart-bypass surgery and a revered figure in Argentina, died in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Today would have been the 96th birthday of Dr. Rene G. Favaloro, who is commemorated in today’s Google Doodle. Here is the full Times obituary from Aug. 1, 2000.

headline: Summer Reads, Recommended by Women of The New York Times
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Four of our journalists, who are also published authors, think you should read these books, too.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines.

headline: Nothing ‘Magic’ About the Flawed Contest to Become U.K. Prime Minister
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: In 1963, a cabal of Conservative insiders called the “magic circle” chose the party’s — and therefore the country’s — leader. Is the current system any better?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Things were simpler for Britain’s governing Conservatives in 1963, when a group of bigwigs called the party’s “magic circle” simply got together and chose the new party leader, and hence prime minister, themselves.

headline: R. Kelly Is Accused of Using Hush Money to Silence Family of Girl in Sex Tape
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Two new federal indictments charge the R&B singer with making child pornography, obstructing justice and other crimes relating to sex with underage girls.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — R. Kelly knew he had a problem.

headline: This Dessert Is Worthy of a Diva, or Two
abstract: What happens when you cross a Pavlova and a peach Melba, dishes named for performers of great renown? The show stops.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a game for the food-obsessed: Instead of contemplating which historical figures you’d invite to a dinner party, picture the dishes you’d serve for the meal. As in oysters Rockefeller followed by tournedos Rossini with a side of Caesar salad?

headline: ‘Crawl’ Review: See You Later, Alligator
abstract: Alexandre Aja’s creature feature stars Kaya Scodelario, Barry Pepper, two toothy predators and one script filled with hokey dialogue.
lead_paragraph: Few genres clear out our cinematic sinuses like a rousing creature feature, as was evident even before the animatronic beastie in “Jaws” lunged awkwardly at Robert Shaw’s boat. Working with or without digital assistance, filmmakers like Spielberg and Bong Joon-ho (with his giddy 2007 masterpiece, “The Host”) understood that terror often derives less from a monster’s realism than from its relevance: Is it a credible element of the world it’s terrorizing?

headline: Emily Blunt Hosts Gala for SpeechTherapy
abstract: And Hunter College celebrates its president, Jennifer J. Raab.
lead_paragraph: And Hunter College celebrates its president, Jennifer J. Raab.

headline: Divided Over Abortion, but Joining Forces for Women’s Workplace Rights
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Women and Girls', 'ABORTION', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Workplace Environment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Unlikely allies have worked together on issues facing pregnant women and new mothers in states that are tightening abortion restrictions.
lead_paragraph: When South Carolina passed a law last year to provide pregnant workers and new mothers with more protections in the workplace, it was driven by an unlikely alliance: supporters of abortion rights working alongside religious groups that oppose them.

headline: Voices for Learning
abstract: Parties were held for the American Institute for Stuttering and Hunter College
lead_paragraph: The American Institute for Stuttering held a gala on July 11 at Guastavino’s restaurant in Manhattan. Emily Blunt hosted, and Nolan Russo Jr. was honored. And Hunter College held a cocktail party on July 10 at the Roosevelt House on the Upper East Side, where the college celebrated its president, Jennifer J. Raab.

headline: Louisiana Prepares for Tropical Storm Barry
abstract: The storm, which is expected to become a hurricane before it crosses land, could drench parts of the state with up to 20 inches of water.
lead_paragraph: With only hours to go before Tropical Storm Barry was expected to strengthen into a hurricane and cross the Louisiana coastline, residents were filling sandbags and stocking up on food and gas on Friday to hunker down for a storm that could drench them with up to 20 inches of rain.

headline: A Gay Teenager Fatally Stabbed a Classmate. Was It Self-Defense?
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Bullies', 'Self-Defense', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Abel Cedeno, who says he had been bullied for being gay, took the stand in his own defense at his manslaughter trial.
lead_paragraph: Abel Cedeno said he never intended to use the knife he brandished in a Bronx high school classroom two years ago.

headline: I’m With ‘They’
abstract: What’s the big deal with gender-neutral pronouns? Some readers and our columnist disagreed.
lead_paragraph: “If we lived in a just, rational, inclusive universe — one in which we were not all so irredeemably obsessed by the particulars of the parts dangling between our fellow humans’ legs … there would be no requirement for you to have to assume my gender just to refer to me in the common tongue,” writes Farhad Manjoo in a recent column, “Call Me ‘They.’” They make the case for adopting gender-neutral pronouns for reasons both cultural and linguistic, but ultimately in the name of inclusivity.

headline: House Passes $733 Billion Defense Bill Checking Trump’s War Powers
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The House passed a provision that would require the president to get Congress’s approval before authorizing military force against Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House gave final approval Friday to a defense bill that would put a liberal stamp on military policy by shackling President Trump’s ability to wage war in Iran and Yemen, restricting the use of military funds at the southwestern border and returning transgender troops to the armed forces.

headline: A Summer Soup for Gazpacho Lovers
abstract: Charred tomatoes give this chilled soup its rustic, smoky flavor.
lead_paragraph: Good tomatoes are finally here. Those of us who endure the long wait for sweet, ripe summer tomatoes are beginning to reap dividends, even if the very best ones won’t arrive until August or September.

headline: Put Some Greens on It
abstract: Add herbs by the handful onto your main dish, until the word “garnish” no longer applies.
lead_paragraph: “Put an egg on it” is still riding its culinary moment: A fried or poached egg draped on top of a dish is a reliable shortcut to making it richer, more filling and more mouthwatering on Instagram (that eye-catching and borderline rude runny yolk).

headline: Trump Again Threatens ‘Major Operation’ Against Undocumented Migrants
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Deportation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Immigration officials said the raids could roll out over days. The Trump administration made similar threats last month without carrying them out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said nationwide raids to arrest and deport undocumented migrants would begin on Sunday in a sweep that immigration officials said could roll out over days, echoing a similar threat last month that was never carried out.

headline: Weight Lifting to Fight Incontinence
abstract: Can vaginal weights help to prevent pelvic floor disorders?
lead_paragraph: Are vaginal weights a safe and effective therapy for stress incontinence or prolapsed uterus?

headline: Judge Clears Way for Amazon and Microsoft to Compete for Giant Pentagon Contract
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Oracle had alleged that Amazon and the Defense Department biased the $10 billion JEDI contract in Amazon’s favor, but was unable to change the Pentagon’s decision.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A federal judge ruled on Friday that Amazon did not unduly influence the shape of one of the largest technology contracts in the Pentagon’s history, setting the stage for the Department of Defense to choose between Amazon and Microsoft for the $10 billion project.

headline: Can a Woman Win the Presidency? Yes, She Can
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Readers respond to doubts about whether America is ready to elect a woman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Hawaii, Rat Lungworm Disease Infects People but Eludes Researchers
abstract: A brain-invading parasite has made nearly 100 people sick in Hawaii in the last decade. How worried should health officials be?
lead_paragraph: A tropical parasite transmitted through rats and snails has caught the attention of health officials in Hawaii. But few scientists have studied the infection once it makes its way into humans, and researchers can’t say for certain whether the disease is becoming more widespread.

headline: House Votes to Extend 9/11 Fund for Lifetimes of First Responders
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The House voted Friday on a $10 billion measure that would replenish a Sept. 11 fund for ailing first responders and extend assistance for the rest of their lives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday approved legislation to replenish a depleted federal fund to compensate emergency workers and others who became ill as a result of their work in the ruins of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, extending it for the lifetime of those who were at Sept. 11’s ground zero.

headline: As Storm Season Begins in the United States, FEMA Is Already Stretched Thin
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Three years of brutal disasters mean fewer trained FEMA workers are available to help victims of Barry -- or whatever storm comes after it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years of crushing natural disasters have left the Federal Emergency Management Agency with even fewer staff available than usual, potentially straining the agency’s ability to help victims of Tropical Storm Barry.

headline: China Vows Sanctions on U.S. Firms Selling Arms to Taiwan
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: More actions against American companies could signal Beijing’s appetite for greater conflict as the trade war enters its second year.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China said on Friday that it would impose sanctions on American companies involved in the recently proposed sale of more than $2 billion in arms to Taiwan. The move could further strain ties between the two large powers, whose governments have been targeting each other’s businesses for punishment as a tariff war boils.

headline: How White Nationalists See What They Want to See in DNA Tests
keywords: ['Whites', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Discrimination', 'Research', 'Sociology']
abstract: What happens when white supremacists on the hate site Stormfront learn that they’re not as white as they thought? Two researchers investigated.

headline: Trump and the Citizenship Question
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Census']
abstract: Readers see nefarious motives in the president’s determination to obtain citizenship data. Also: The labor secretary resigns over the Jeffrey Epstein furor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Twitter Loves the Opera Diva Karita Mattila. And She Loves It Back.
abstract: The star soprano says social media was a “lifesaver” after her divorce, and it has redefined her relationship with music.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — On Karita Mattila’s Twitter page — where her profile photo is a refined portrait, but the background image is a blurry cellphone shot of her cheesing joyfully — you’ll find a simple biography that begins: “Finnish soprano. Going strong. Having fun.”

headline: The Playlist: Beyoncé’s ‘Lion King’ Anthem, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Billie Eilish and Justin Bieber, Jenny Hval, Angelica Garcia and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: District of Columbia Opens New Investigative Front Into N.R.A.
abstract: Karl A. Racine, attorney general for the District of Columbia, has issued subpoenas to the N.R.A. and its large affiliated charity.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general for the District of Columbia, Karl A. Racine, has opened a new investigative front against the National Rifle Association, issuing subpoenas on Friday to the gun group and a large affiliated charity.

headline: Brazil’s President May Appoint Son, Friend to the Trumps, as Ambassador to U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro said his son Eduardo’s friendship with President Trump’s sons would make him an effective envoy. The idea immediately provoked criticism.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil is weighing appointing his third son, Eduardo Bolsonaro, as ambassador to the United States, arguing that his son’s friendship with President Trump’s sons would make him an effective envoy.

headline: At Tap City Festival, at Least the Shoes Are Polished
abstract: Aside from a few standouts, performances at the annual tap dance showcase in New York were herd-like in sound and visually bland.
lead_paragraph: “Tap dance is alive and kicking,” Tony Waag, the director of the New York City Tap Festival, said at Symphony Space on Thursday. “So much is going on, so much of it right here on this stage.”

headline: A 1995 Novel Predicted Trump’s America
abstract: William H. Gass’s “The Tunnel” explores eerily resonant themes of midcentury Western fascism.
lead_paragraph: “Consider how the titles of tyrants change,” the historian William Frederick Kohler once wrote. “We shall suffer no more Emperors, Kings, Czars, Shahs or Caesars, to lop off our limbs and burn our homes, kiddo, defile our women and bugger our boys; the masses make such appointments now; the masses love tyranny; they demand it; they dance to it; they feel that their hand is forming the First Citizen’s Fist; so we shall murder more modestly in future: beneath the banners of ‘Il Duce,’ ‘Der Führer,’ the General Secretary or the Party Chairman, the C.E.O. of something. I suspect that the first dictator of this country will be called Coach.”

headline: An outtake from “The Plan to Elect Republican Women,” an episode of “The Daily”
abstract: Julie Davis explains why the primary runoff in North Carolina’s Third Congressional District was an important test case for the Republican strategy to elect more women.
lead_paragraph: Julie Davis explains why the primary runoff in North Carolina’s Third Congressional District was an important test case for the Republican strategy to elect more women.

headline: Elka Gilmore, Chef Who Blended the Old and the New, Dies at 59
abstract: “I don’t really know what ‘fusion’ means,” she said, but at restaurants in California and New York she displayed a knack for combining flavors.
lead_paragraph: Elka Gilmore, an innovative West Coast chef who helped redefine fusion cuisine in the 1990s, died on July 6 in San Francisco. She was 59.

headline: Spain’s First Recognized ‘Stolen Baby’ Finds She Was Adopted Not Abducted
abstract: Inés Madrigal, a Spanish woman at the heart of nationwide scandal over stolen and trafficked babies, said she was the victim of an illegal adoption rather than an abduction.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish woman at the heart of a nationwide scandal involving babies who were stolen and trafficked over a four-decade period said on Thursday that she had discovered she was the victim of an illegal adoption rather than an abduction.

headline: The Life Cycle of a Beach Read
abstract: The cover is clean and brand-new, the pages are crisp — and then your vacation begins. Jessica Olien illustrates the path to the dog-eared and waterlogged.

headline: Review: A Meticulous Artist, Numb to the Touch, in ‘Reborning’
abstract: This play by Zayd Dohrn, about a victim of a horrific crime who grows up to be a dollmaker, is a dark comedy — with a touch of horror.
lead_paragraph: The tabloids called her “The Dumpster Darling” for the way she was found as an infant, her torso stabbed, her hands burned with chemicals, her little body wrapped in plastic and left to die — presumably by her parents.

headline: Abrons Arts Center’s Coming Season to Explore Difficult Topics
abstract: The 2019-2020 slate includes performance pieces that deal with blackface, environmental destruction and colonialism.
lead_paragraph: Abrons Arts Center doesn’t shy away from presenting work that deals with sensitive subjects. It’s part of the organization’s mission to address issues, like racial inequity and the legacy of colonialism, that affect the communities surrounding it on the Lower East Side in Manhattan. In the coming season, announced on Friday, audiences will be invited to confront something particularly taboo: blackface.

headline: Alexander Acosta Won’t Be the Last Trump Official to Resign
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Thank goodness for career civil servants.
lead_paragraph: And then there were none.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Mötley Crüe to Cinderella
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: OUR HARLEM: Seven Days of Cooking, Music and Soul at the Red Rooster, by Marcus Samuelsson, read by the author. (Audible.) An audiobook original of the celebrated chef and restaurateur’s homage to the New York City neighborhood, through its food and culture.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: It was never about busing. Where are all the Bob Ross paintings? Aziz Ansari speaks. Farewell, Ross Perot. Visiting the Oracle of Delphi. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It might be a newsy one. We’re watching a big storm, planned immigration raids and some tennis. Here, though, are some great stories — and a Bob Ross video (watch it now!) — from the week you may have missed.

headline: China’s Retort Over Its Mass Detentions: Praise From Russia and Saudi Arabia
abstract: After 22 countries deplored China’s treatment of Muslims in the Xinjiang region, 37 nations praised China’s “contribution to the international human rights cause.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — China fumed this week after 22 mostly Western countries rebuked its mass detention of Muslims in the restive Xinjiang region. On Friday the Chinese delivered their answer: praise from even more countries saying China has made Xinjiang safe and happy.

headline: Claims That Obama ‘Yanked’ Citizenship Question From Census Are False
keywords: ['Census', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: This talking point from supporters of President Trump is wrong in several ways.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday backed away from efforts to add a question about citizenship to the 2020 census after insisting that he would press on despite a Supreme Court ruling that the administration had not provided an adequate reason for including the question. Throughout his fight, a number of prominent conservative voices and members of his staff have amplified an inaccurate talking point that former President Barack Obama had eliminated the question.

headline: T Suggests: A Rediscovered Funk Record, a New Gallery Upstate and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always felt that being in a room full of queer people as a queer person creates the uncanny sensation of experiencing the past and present at the same time: L.G.B.T.Q.+ people are never not aware of the activism and its art, the homophobia and its history, the disease and its death — all those bodies missing from the room — that have spurred them to live increasingly public lives, to gather and build an ever more powerful, visible, vibrant community. I thought about this again while viewing “Particular Voices: Photographs of LGBTQ Writers, Artists and Activists, 1980s – 1990s,” a show of 53 black-and-white portrait photographs taken by Robert Giard that are on display through July 26 at Daniel Cooney’s Chelsea gallery.

headline: A Q&A With Michael
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Women and Girls', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: You asked on Twitter. We answered.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get this by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: For 30 Minutes on a Hot Friday Morning, Trump Lashes Out at a Range of Critics
abstract: The president’s targets included Bill de Blasio, Paul D. Ryan, the outgoing British ambassador and the press. But he said that Nancy Pelosi was not a racist.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking for over 30 minutes in the hot sun on Friday morning, President Trump lashed out at his critics in no particular order, heaping vitriol on everyone from Democrats running for president to the former Republican House speaker, not to mention a foreign ambassador and the press.

headline: George F. Will on Conservatism’s Homelessness
abstract: Will discusses “The Conservative Sensibility,” and David Maraniss talks about “A Good American Family: The Red Scare and My Father.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: What Is the S-400? The Russian Missile System in Turkey That Irks the Pentagon
abstract: Turkey’s purchase of the S-400 missile defense system could give Russian technicians access to technology in U.S. warplanes that Turkey wants to buy.
lead_paragraph: The first parts of a sophisticated, Russian-supplied surface-to-air missile system, known as the S-400, arrived in Turkey on Friday.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Facebook Fine of About $5 Billion
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Social Media', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: If approved by the Justice Department, the settlement would be the biggest fine levied by the federal government against a technology company.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has approved a fine of roughly $5 billion against Facebook for mishandling users’ personal information, according to three people briefed on the vote, in what would be a landmark settlement that signals a newly aggressive stance by regulators toward the country’s most powerful technology companies.

headline: Jerry Lawson, Lead Singer of the Persuasions, Is Dead at 75
abstract: Mr. Lawson and his colleagues revived the lost art of a cappella singing and attracted a loyal following that included Joni Mitchell and Frank Zappa.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Lawson, who for four decades was the lead singer of the Persuasions, a group that revived the art of a cappella singing and attracted a loyal worldwide following, died on Wednesday in Phoenix. He was 75.

headline: Hector Figueroa: The Labor Movement Can Rise Again
abstract: “It is heartbreaking to witness our movement risk near-irrelevance when workers are ready to take action.”
lead_paragraph: As the American economy continues its record-breaking expansion, the question for labor leaders across the country is: What can unions do to make economic growth work for the workers left behind by the bonanza of the past decade?

headline: Extra! Extra! Starbucks Will Stop Selling Newspapers
abstract: Beginning in September, the coffee giant will no longer carry copies of three national newspapers and select local papers.
lead_paragraph: It’s the quintessential Starbucks experience: Walk in, order a piping hot cup of coffee and sit back with a newspaper.

headline: Migrants in Mexico Face Kidnappings and Violence While Awaiting Immigration Hearings in U.S.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: The expansion of a U.S.-Mexican migrant-enforcement deal has left thousands of migrants stranded in dangerous Mexican cities.
lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — He waited 19 days for an appointment to apply for asylum in the United States, hoping to stay safe until his number came up.

headline: E.P.A. Plans to Curtail the Ability of Communities to Oppose Pollution Permits
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The agency is preparing to weaken rules that, for a quarter-century, have given communities a voice in deciding how much industrial pollution may legally be released nearby.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to weaken rules that for the past quarter-century have given communities a voice in deciding how much pollution may legally be released by nearby power plants and factories.

headline: Epstein Paid $350,000 to Possible Witnesses Against Him, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Federal prosecutors made the allegations in an effort to have bail denied for Mr. Epstein, the financier facing sex-trafficking charges.
lead_paragraph: Just days after a newspaper exposé last November drew new attention to Jeffrey Epstein’s predatory behavior toward young women, he wired $350,000 to two people close to him, federal prosecutors revealed on Friday.

headline: Fernando Corbató, a Father of Your Computer (and Your Password), Dies at 93
abstract: In a breakthrough in the 1960s, he showed that computers could be used interactively with quick results, and also made secure from others’ using them.
lead_paragraph: Fernando Corbató, whose work on computer time-sharing in the 1960s helped pave the way for the personal computer, as well as the computer password, died on Friday at a nursing home in Newburyport, Mass. He was 93.

headline: Hundreds of Undocumented Migrants Occupy Panthéon Monument in Paris
abstract: The protesters, who called themselves “Black Vests,” occupied the memorial complex for hours as they demanded legal status.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hundreds of undocumented migrants stormed the Panthéon monument on Friday, demanding that the French government pay more attention to their plight and grant them legal status.

headline: On Pigeon Patrol, Rufus the Hawk Rules the Skies Over Wimbledon
abstract: The famed hawk keeps pigeons at bay so the courts and the players can remain … clean.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Imagine the fluttering kerfuffle.

headline: Acosta, New Orleans, Facebook: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Janet Mock Can’t Travel Without
abstract: For the trans-rights activist and producer of the FX show, “Pose,” must-have travel items include magazines, a sleep mask and bikinis for every day of the week.
lead_paragraph: Janet Mock was already famous for her work as a magazine editor and trans-rights activist when she added writer, director and producer to her résumé with the debut of “Pose,” a TV show about the lives of gay and trans people in New York in the late 1980s. The second season premiered June 11 on FX.

headline: Fernando de la Rúa, Ill-Fated President of Argentina, Dies at 81
abstract: He was elected easily in 1999. But he resigned two years later amid a spectacular economic collapse, leaving the presidential palace by helicopter.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Fernando de la Rúa, who resigned as president of Argentina after two years in 2001 amid one of the most spectacular economic collapses in modern history, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Belén de Escobar, in Buenos Aires Province. He was 81.

headline: Dwight Gooden Arrested on Drug Charges in New Jersey
abstract: Police charged the former Yankee and Mets star after a traffic stop last month.
lead_paragraph: Dwight Gooden, the former standout pitcher for the Mets and Yankees, was arrested last month in New Jersey and charged with cocaine possession and driving under the influence.

headline: 6 Glorious Ways to Do Corn on the Cob
abstract: Plain melted butter is good; these toppings are better. Here are six wildly delicious ways to dress up sweet summer corn.
lead_paragraph: We ask a lot of elotes, the Mexican corn covered in mayonnaise, cotija, chile powder and lime. They are the only common cob topping at cookouts beyond butter. (They’re also a great dish to bring up when someone foolishly says they hate mayo, because in elotes, this divisive condiment is both the key ingredient and undetectable.)

headline: Trump’s Ominous Attempt to Redefine Human Rights
abstract: From the administration that brought you the camps, a faith-based effort to undercut America’s role in defending people’s dignity.
lead_paragraph: For the Trump administration to establish a “Commission on Unalienable Rights” to examine the meaning of human rights, as it did this month, is a little like Saudi Arabia forming a commission on multiparty democracy or North Korea a commission on how to end famine. It would be hilarious if it weren’t so ominous.

headline: Hector Figueroa, Union Leader With Impact, Dies at 57
abstract: As head of New York’s Service Employees union, he successfully campaigned for better pay and working conditions for more than 170,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Hector Figueroa, who as president of one of the country’s most influential labor unions led successful campaigns for better pay and working conditions for thousands of low-wage workers, died on Thursday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 57.

headline: Machu Picchu Is in Unnecessary Danger
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'AIRPORTS', 'Incas', 'World Heritage Sites', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Land Use Policies', 'Indigenous People', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A new international airport in Peru would undermine exactly what tourists are coming so far to see.
lead_paragraph: CUSCO, Peru — The Andean village Chinchero, which sits above the Urubamba Valley, is one of the most breathtakingly beautiful landscapes. Majestic terraces made by the Incas stretch out into the vast plateau. Fields of quinoa, amaranth, potato and corn plants form a tapestry of shades — green, red and gold. Sweeping views of snow-laden peaks known as Apus, the name given to the spirits of the mountains in Inca mythology, dominate the horizon.

headline: Alex Navab, Prominent Wall Street Dealmaker, Is Dead at 53
abstract: He was once considered to be in line to run the private equity giant KKR and had recently started his own ambitious firm.
lead_paragraph: Alex Navab, a prominent financier who was once considered a potential successor to the Wall Street titans Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, died on July 7 while vacationing with his family in Greece. He was 53.

headline: Katrina on Its Mind, New Orleans Keeps an Anxious Eye on Tropical Storm Barry
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Levees and Dams']
abstract: The trauma of levee failures loomed large as residents scrambled to stock food, fill sandbags and pump their cars with gas.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Water can come at you from multiple angles in a city surrounded by it. Joseph Thomas, 51, remembers how it came into his neighborhood last time.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Crimes of Grindelwald’ and ‘Clique’
abstract: The latest installment in the “Fantastic Beasts” series airs on HBO. And a British thriller’s second season arrives on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: FANTASTIC BEASTS: THE CRIMES OF GRINDELWALD (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. We’ve come a long way since J.K. Rowling’s “Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone” hit the big screen. That movie spawned seven sequels and a spinoff franchise that began with “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” in 2016. “The Crimes of Grindelwald” is the second in that series and the prequel to the Potter films. Our resident “magizoologist,” Newt Scamander (Eddie Redmayne), sets out to stop the menacing wizard Grindelwald (Johnny Depp in true Depp form) from disrupting the peace between magical and nonmagical beings and sparking a movement of pure-blood wizard domination. (The metaphors are hard to miss.) While the film upholds Rowling’s limitless creativity — the scenes are rich with detail and stunning visuals — she packs it with so many characters and subplots that you may be left searching for a single thread to hold onto.

headline: Goldbugs for Trump
abstract: They sold their principles a long time ago.
lead_paragraph: Before going to the White House, Donald Trump demanded that the Fed raise interest rates despite high unemployment and low inflation. Now he’s demanding rate cuts, even though the unemployment rate is much lower and inflation at least a bit higher. To be fair, there is a real economic argument for rate cuts as insurance against a possible slowdown. But it’s clear that Trump’s motives are and always have been purely political: he wanted the Fed to hurt President Obama, and now he wants it to boost his own reelection chances.

For generations, in mines and the nearby steel mills that coal made possible, his family, like many others, has relied on jobs in the fossil fuel industry. Mr. Thomas knows the sacrifices that come with the work. His father, Elmer, died of black lung in 1995. His brother Robert was killed in an accident at the Maple Creek Mine in Bentleyville, Pa., in 1996.

headline: Please Touch Me
abstract: Has intimacy gone so far out of style that it’s poised for a comeback?
lead_paragraph: In 2003, I started working for a Paris-based trend forecaster as a futurist, collaborating with clients like L’Oréal on what the next trends would be in texture, shade and scent for cosmetics and skin care products. I got the job largely because I understood the importance of using email subject lines, which my boss, the only other employee there, did not. I was living in Paris post-college with a fancy comparative literature degree and no visa, an overeducated illegal immigrant of sorts, and my boss tended to pay me in discarded haute couture clothing and oysters from her lover’s wine bar instead of cash. But I stayed because it turned out that I had an affinity for forecasting.

abstract: A verdict determined that the Eritrean man arrested in Sudan in 2016 was not the smuggling kingpin that authorities believed him to be.
lead_paragraph: A court in Sicily has ordered the immediate release of an Eritrean man accused more than three years ago of managing an extensive people-smuggling network for those trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Saving Bernie Sanders
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: The revolutionary needs to make a case that he can be a pragmatist.
lead_paragraph: We’re only two debates-and-their-aftermaths deep into the Democratic primary campaign, and already one of my 2020 scenarios is looking wobbly. This spring I prophesied that Bernie Sanders had a chance of imitating Ronald Reagan’s leap between 1976 and 1980 — in which a former insurgent dismissed as too old and too ideological became a nominee and then a history-making president. But now in summer Sanders is struggling — not plummeting but leaking support, watching money and media attention pass to others, laboring to hold his base rather than expand it.

headline: 7 Died in a Motorcycle Crash. How Their Club of Former Marines Is Mourning Them.
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: A motorcycle club of ex-Marines struggles to pick up the pieces after a horrific crash killed its leader and six other members and supporters.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Of the seven funerals, Albert Mazza Jr.’s was the last. It seemed fitting, since he had been their leader. A few years ago, he had helped establish the Jarheads Motorcycle Club, a motley crew of honorably discharged Marines who raise money for veterans in need.

headline: Are We Finished?
abstract: Caitlin Reid will have the last word.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — After last weekend’s complexities, we have a breezy grid today that I dare say doesn’t take too much explaining. Caitlin Reid makes her Sunday debut after three dailies, which included a really good Friday puzzle from last month.

headline: If the Supreme Court Won’t Prevent Gerrymandering, Who Will?
abstract: A progressive take on states’ rights can come to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: Progressives have long looked to federal courts to guard the rights of racial minorities and dissenters. But that protection is weakening. Faced with the enormous injustice of  partisan gerrymandering, the Supreme Court last month permitted politicians drawing election district maps to discriminate by party and even potentially mask their racial “packing” and “cracking” as mere partisanship. To fill this growing gap, reformers should take an unexpected route: states’ rights.

headline: Man Attacking ICE Detention Center Is Fatally Shot by the Police
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The man was armed with a rifle and was throwing “incendiary devices” on Saturday in Tacoma, Wash., officials said.
lead_paragraph: The police fatally shot a man who was attacking an immigration detention center in Tacoma, Wash., on Saturday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Top Ocasio-Cortez Aide Becomes a Symbol of Democratic Division
abstract: From his perch as Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s chief of staff, Saikat Chakrabarti has waged war on fellow Democrats. The party leadership has had enough.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democratic leaders, their patience clearly fraying, signaled this weekend to Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s outspoken top aide that his seeming efforts to lead an insurrection against more moderate Democrats would no longer be tolerated — a message also aimed at the freshman congresswoman who employs him.

headline: Pence Defends Conditions at Migrant Detention Centers in Texas
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence toured two Border Patrol facilities on Friday, later saying they were “providing care that every American would be proud of.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence played down reports of overcrowding and unsanitary conditions at two migrant detention centers in Texas that he visited on Friday, but he acknowledged the gravity of the humanitarian crisis unfolding along the United States’ southwestern border.

headline: Hurricane Barry Spares New Orleans (So Far), as Inland Cities Brace for Floods
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Floods', 'Levees and Dams', 'Rescues', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)']
abstract: Barry was downgraded to a tropical storm as it made landfall and continued to weaken. But the threat of flooding remains high.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Hurricane Barry crept onto the shores of Louisiana west of flood-weary New Orleans on Saturday, drawing cautious optimism from city residents who saw little rainfall from the storm as of evening, and from officials in western coastal parishes that were drenched and battered but had prepared for much worse.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Sweetbitter’ and ‘Grantchester’
abstract: A young waitress finds her footing in the second season of “Sweetbitter.” And the British mystery series “Grantchester” is back for Season 4.
lead_paragraph: SWEETBITTER 9 p.m. on Starz. Last year Starz added this drama series — adapted from the novel by Stephanie Danler — to the list of shows about young women navigating life in the Big Apple (think “Girls” and “Sex and the City”). The focus here is on Tess (Ella Purnell), a 20-something naïf who leaves the Midwest and is offered a trial position at a high-end Manhattan restaurant. In the first season, she discovered the inner-workings of the dining world, got a taste of New York City night life and found a love interest (or two). Season 2 debuts with two back-to-back episodes and picks up after Tess has been handed the job. No longer the new girl in town, she’s a little more at ease but realizes there is plenty to learn if she wants to keep her head above water.

headline: The 1977 Blackout in New York City Happened Exactly 42 Years Ago
abstract: On the anniversary of the enormous blackout, another one sent parts of Manhattan into darkness.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday at 6:47 p.m., parts of Midtown Manhattan and the West Side went dark.

headline: How Some New Yorkers Found Bliss in the Blackout
abstract: They roasted hot dogs on the pavement and cracked open champagne from a warming fridge. “I loved the darkness,” one said.
lead_paragraph: A major blackout had knocked out power to much of the West Side of Manhattan on Saturday night, but Danielle Allen sat in the crook of a doorway with the blissed-out look of a sunbather.

headline: ‘The Last Leonardo’ Looks Into a $450 Million Mystery
abstract: Ben Lewis’s new book explores the purported 500-year history of “Salvator Mundi,” a painting of Christ that shattered auction records in 2017.
lead_paragraph: In May 2015, Christie’s sold Pablo Picasso’s “Women of Algiers” for $179.4 million, the highest price for a painting at auction up to that point. Two and a half years later, Christie’s sold Leonardo da Vinci’s “Salvator Mundi,” a portrait of Christ, for $450.3 million. In his new book, “The Last Leonardo,” the author and documentary filmmaker Ben Lewis writes about the painting’s twisty, contentious road to the auction block and beyond.

headline: Pete Buttigieg’s Life in the Closet
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: And why it took him until he was 33 to come out.
lead_paragraph: The closet that Pete Buttigieg built for himself in the late 1990s and 2000s was a lot like the ones that other gay men of his age and ambition hid inside. He dated women, deepened his voice and furtively looked at MySpace and Friendster profiles of guys who had come out — all while wondering when it might be safe for him to do so too.

headline: Tropical Storm Barry: Drenching Rains Still a Menace
abstract: Barry, now a tropical storm, is slowly moving northward over central Louisiana, and life-threatening flooding rains remain a primary threat, officials say.
lead_paragraph: The center of the storm was about 20 miles northeast of Shreveport, La., on Sunday evening, and not going anywhere in a hurry. Most of southeast Louisiana remained under a flash flood watch until 7 p.m. Sunday because of how slowly Barry was moving, and flood watches were upgraded to warnings around Baton Rouge. The weather system was expected to move north through Arkansas Sunday night.

Johnson, a former college wrestler convicted of failing to disclose to sexual partners that he was H.I.V. positive in a racially charged case that reignited calls to  re-examine laws that criminalize H.I.V. exposure, walked out of the Boonville Correctional Center in Missouri 25 years earlier than expected.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: We have six new ways to make grilled corn on the cob. Cacio e pepe! Buffalo sauce! Miso butter!

I like a steamed cob with butter as much as the next guy in line at the bank, and a grilled one smeared with homemade crema, hit with Tajín and drizzled with lime juice is an astonishing treat.

headline: What Makes Michael R. Jackson Tick, and What Ticks Him Off
abstract: The young, gay, black creator of the musical “A Strange Loop” talks about his process, Liz Phair, soap operas and just about everything else.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Jackson — playwright, composer, lyricist and superfan — sang along to every single song at the recent Liz Phair concert in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park. He even knew the obscure “Ant in Alaska.” He took photos and beamed, he offered learned asides about alternate lyrics. When Ms. Phair launched into “Divorce Song,” Mr. Jackson let out a piercing scream that may still be echoing in the wilds of Park Slope.

headline: Hurricane Barry and the New Normal
abstract: Can we afford to leave the city? Will our insurance cover an out-of-state delivery?
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Before I left New Orleans on Thursday, in advance of Hurricane Barry, I put a photograph of my grandmother’s family, taken before World War II, into a waterproof bag. I wrote my phone number in permanent marker on the outside, tied it to a life preserver along with a few other things I couldn’t bear to lose and put them in the attic. I trust they will be there when I return home on Monday.

abstract: Two senior members of Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló’s cabinet have stepped down amid a widening political crisis in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A political crisis engulfed Puerto Rico over the weekend, prompting the departure of two senior members of the government and threatening Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló, who found himself increasingly isolated in office and no longer supported by leaders of his own party.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Bankruptcy Plan Is Almost Done, and It Could Start a Fight
abstract: The island territory is preparing to present its complete restructuring plan for its $124 billion debt. Court challenges are almost certain, but if the plan survives it could be a road map for troubled states.
lead_paragraph: After three years of negotiations, Puerto Rico’s federal overseers are at last finishing up a plan to complete the restructuring of the island’s roughly $124 billion in debt. To resolve the biggest government financial collapse in United States history, they have had to untangle the island’s thorny finances, negotiate with creditors and figure out how to do it without endangering the livelihoods of retirees who rely solely on their pensions.

headline: Don’t Count on Government to Protect Your Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Blockchain (Technology)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Let’s look to technologies like blockchain and other innovations to keep our data private.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that Congress proposed a law that made postage free in the United States. Even in the digital age, this would be quite convenient. The only catch? In exchange for free mail, postmasters would be permitted to open your mail and read our letters and bills. The benefit, postmasters would insist, is they would know when you’re planning a family vacation. And then the post office could send you hotel recommendations or advice for the best restaurants and activities.

headline: The High Price of Multitasking
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Social Media', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Brain']
abstract: We all do it. The question is how.
lead_paragraph: Not only do smartphones provide unprecedented access to information, they provide unprecedented opportunities to multitask. Any activity can be accompanied by music, selfies or social media updates. Of course, some people pick poor times to tweet or text, and lawmakers have stepped in. Forty-eight states have banned texting while driving. In Honolulu, it’s illegal to text or even look at your phone while crossing the street, and in the Netherlands they’ve banned texting while biking.

headline: Trump’s Tweets Prove That He Is a Raging Racist
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Whites', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: It is undeniably true that America’s president opposes diversity.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump keeps trying to convince any disbelieving holdouts that he is a raging racist. At least, that’s how I imagine his motives. In truth, it is more likely that his truest nature is simply being revealed, again and again, and he is using his own racism to appeal to the racism in the people who support him.

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Hsieh Su-wei and Barbora Strycova were ready hours before the scheduled start of the Wimbledon women’s doubles final, which was planned as the third match on Centre Court on Saturday.
