lead_paragraph: In the video Op-Ed above, children read testimonies given by young migrants detained in Customs and Border Protection facilities. They reveal harrowing stories of children living in cages, going hungry and tending to infants without their parents.

headline: A Home Away From Home
abstract: To Jimmy Lozano, Warique has the spirit of the restaurant his cousins once ran out of their house in Pucallpa in eastern Peru.
lead_paragraph: To Jimmy Lozano, Warique has the spirit of the restaurant his cousins once ran out of their house in Pucallpa in eastern Peru.

headline: Sanders and Biden Fight Over Health Care, and It’s Personal
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: “Unfortunately, he is sounding like Donald Trump,” Senator Bernie Sanders said of Joe Biden, as the two Democratic candidates spar over one of the most important issues in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders does not understand Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s position on health care. To Mr. Sanders, the health care system is broken, and the only way to fix it is to replace it with his signature policy plan known as Medicare for All.

headline: Peruvian, Fortifying and Frank, at Warique in Queens

headline: When You Display Ai Weiwei, Beware of Cats
abstract: For the sake of their collection, Trey and Jenny Laird had to crawl around to retrieve hundreds of pieces of a tabletop work upset by a pet.
lead_paragraph: “Old lady house,” is the way Trey and Jenny Laird describe their four-story Upper East Side townhome, but the contemporary art inside — by the likes of Cindy Sherman, Louise Lawler, Michaël Borremans, Jenny Holzer and Tracey Emin — does not seem outdated in the least.

headline: New York Galleries: What to See Right Now
abstract: Joseph Elmer Yoakum’s delirious vistas; Olga Balema’s discreet sculptures; and a 12-artist show, “Just Painting,” rich with visual echoes.
lead_paragraph: The visionary landscapist Joseph Elmer Yoakum (1888-1972) has been categorized as an outsider, self-taught or folk artist. Whichever: His place in the expanding canon of 20th-century American art is assured, both for his achievement and influence. The latest evidence of Yoakum’s originality is this enthralling exhibition, among the largest ever devoted to his work. It features nearly 70 of the artist’s delirious vistas of undulant hills, mountains and rock formations, variously striated, patterned and creviced, rendered in pale browns and pastels of colored pencil burnished to resemble watercolor. Defined by double outlines, Yoakum’s geological elements have a curious autonomy: They heave, lean and push against one another, but they also evoke soft creased flesh, voluptuous but slightly abstracted. Sudden breaks in the terrain offer views of tiny trees, distorting space and scale and intensifying the sexual undercurrent.

headline: Well, This Is Clearly Wrong
abstract: When you see an older man taking photographs of underage boys in a locker room, say something.
lead_paragraph: The summer day camp at our local Y.M.C.A. is in session. Recently, I saw a teenage counselor lead a line of preschool boys into the locker room to change for their swim lesson. They were like an adorable row of ducklings! Then I saw an older man — a friendly looking, grandfatherly type — take out his iPhone and photograph the boys while they were changing into their swimsuits. It was hard to decide what to do in that moment, so I did nothing. But this scene has stayed with me. Should I have spoken up?

headline: This New Liquid Is Magnetic, and Mesmerizing
abstract: Scientists have created “soft” magnets that can flow and change shape, and that could be a boon to medicine and robotics.
lead_paragraph: Lodestone, a naturally-occurring iron oxide, was the first persistently magnetic material known to humans. The Han Chinese used it for divining boards 2,200 years ago; ancient Greeks puzzled over why iron was attracted to it; and, Arab merchants placed it in bowls of water to watch the magnet point the way to Mecca. In modern times, scientists have used magnets to read and record data on hard drives and form detailed images of bones, cells and even atoms.

headline: In Praise of Wright Morris
abstract: Peter Orner, author of “Maggie Brown & Others,” on a writer who specializes in “American oddness.”
lead_paragraph: The mystery of Wright Morris isn’t why he’s so forgotten, it’s that he was ever much known in the first place. Because it’s true that Morris was, if never a household literary name, at least mentioned among (need I say it?) the male literary heavyweights of his day. A finalist for the National Book Award numerous times, Morris won it twice, in 1957 for “Field of Vision,” and in 1980 for his final novel, “Plains Song.” A celebrated photographer as well, Morris’s work was exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art as early as 1941. All told, between 1942 and 1986, Morris published 33 books, including novels, prose fiction and photographs (what he referred to as photo-texts), essay and story collections, and memoirs. A Nebraska native, Wright Morris spent much of his life in California remembering, and more important, reimagining, the Midwest. He died in 1998 at the age of 88.

headline: What Is the Heat Index? Is it the Heat, the Humidity, or Both?

I scan the space, my eyes noting the woman on the operating table, and make a quick calculation of where the light hits each corner, which parts of the room are too dark to photograph.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: July 12-18
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: At least 92 pro-government forces and 45 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
lead_paragraph: At least 92 pro-government forces and 45 civilians were killed during another bloody week of fighting in Afghanistan. The deadliest of the attacks took place in Badghis Province, where 46 Afghan commandos who had been planning a raid on a Taliban prison ended up near the house of the Taliban shadow governor in the Aab Kamari District, where both sides fought for seven hours. Thirty-five commandos and four civilians were killed; four others were taken prisoners by insurgents. Elsewhere, in Nangarhar Province, nine people were killed when a child carried out a suicide attack at a wedding party in Pachiragam District. Among those killed was Malik Tor, a pro-government militia commander, and eight civilians, including a child. Fourteen others were wounded. On Saturday, Sgt. Maj. James G. “Ryan” Sartor, a Special Forces company sergeant major, was killed as a result of injuries sustained from enemy small-arms fire during combat operations, the American military announced.

McAleenan, the acting secretary of homeland security, of leading an agency with an “empathy deficit” during a hearing on Thursday that focused on the separation of migrant children from their parents and reports of poor conditions at holding facilities near the border.

headline: Mortimer Caplin, Tactful but Tough Tax Collector, Dies at 103
abstract: As I.R.S. commissioner in the Kennedy administration, Mr. Caplin promised to be “both reasonable and vigorous” and largely succeeded.
lead_paragraph: Mortimer Caplin, who as Internal Revenue commissioner in the early 1960s was credited with making taxpaying more tolerable for the majority of Americans who do so voluntarily and tougher for the rest to avoid or evade, died on Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 103.

headline: Aaron Rosand, Renowned Violinist With a Famous Fiddle, Dies at 92
abstract: For decades he played a 1741 instrument. Then he sold it and gave $1.5 million of the proceeds to his alma mater.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Rosand, a leading violinist who closed out an astonishingly long career with a dramatic, emotion-filled gesture, selling his beloved rare violin for some $10 million and donating $1.5 million of that to a music institute, died on July 9 in White Plains. He was 92.

headline: The Real Meaning of ‘Send Her Back!’
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: It’s become the message of Donald Trump’s presidency.

What is excruciatingly clear, and what matters most right now, is that he has chosen to ground his politics and his presidency in fomenting racial hatred. Whatever he may feel in his bones, he is an avid race warrior.

headline: New York City Triathlon Canceled This Year, but Will Still Be in July in 2020
abstract: The decision to cancel it came a day after Mayor de Blasio urged race directors not to hold the event on Sunday, when temperatures in the high 90s are expected.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Triathlon was canceled on Thursday, a day after Mayor Bill de Blasio urged race directors not to hold the event as scheduled on Sunday, when severe heat is expected. But race organizers said Friday that the event would continue to be in July for the foreseeable future despite problems with the heat.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Queer Eye’ and ‘Wonders of the Moon’
abstract: The Fab Five are back for a fourth season, and BBC America revisits mankind’s fascination with the moon.
lead_paragraph: QUEER EYE Stream on Netflix. After bringing their infectious brand of self-love to New York City for World Pride, the Fab Five are back for the fourth season of “Queer Eye,” serving up new looks, new renovations and newfound confidence to a handful of men and women in the Kansas City area. And this season, the gang gets personal, revisiting the grooming specialist Jonathan Van Ness’s alma mater, to make over his former orchestra teacher. “You have literally saved people’s lives,” Van Ness tells the teacher in the emotional trailer for Season 4. “Mine included.” Needless to say, you should have some tissues handy.

headline: Roller Coaster of Love
abstract: After my sister was injured by a roller coaster, would we be tempting fate to ride again?
lead_paragraph: Last summer my stomach dropped as I watched my children make their first ascent on the classic wooden roller coaster in Arnolds Park, Iowa. I rode on it as a child and my parents and grandparents had ridden it before me. I remembered throwing my arms in the air with my sister as we screamed, trying to coax a bit more velocity into an already thrilling moment. I wanted my own children to have this sort of fun; I didn’t want to be a weird killjoy.

headline: Safe Deposit Boxes Aren’t Safe
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Safes and Vaults', 'Bank Robberies']
abstract: When Philip Poniz opened Box 105 at his local Wells Fargo, he discovered it was empty — and that he was totally unprotected by federal law.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, when Philip Poniz moved to New Jersey from Colorado, he needed a well-protected place to stash his collection of rare watches. He had been gathering unusual pieces since he was a teenager in 1960s Poland, fascinated by their intricate mechanics. His hobby became his profession, and by the time of his relocation, Mr. Poniz was an internationally known expert in the history and restoration of high-end timepieces.

headline: Richard Curtis’s Five Places to Visit in London
abstract: The filmmaker portrays an unblemished city in one British romantic comedy after the other. In real life, the screenwriter of “Yesterday” gives his spin on favorite spots.
lead_paragraph: There’s London and then there’s Richard Curtis’s London. The 62-year-old filmmaker has spun the city into a cozy, romantic oasis in back-to-back cinematic hits — from “Four Weddings and a Funeral” and “Notting Hill” to ”Love Actually.” His latest film is “Yesterday,” a comedy about the enduring power of the Beatles.

headline: At Detention Camps and Shelters, Art Helps Migrant Youths Find Their Voices
keywords: ['Art', 'Immigration Detention', 'Children and Childhood', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Works by confined children show hopefulness in the face of stress, and may help in the healing.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — The young migrants often arrived at night. They were teenagers from Central and South America, brought by border agents to the Tornillo Detention Facility and led to rows of metal bunk beds in military tents ringed by barbed wire. Human touch, even a simple hug, was rare inside this secured temporary city, where nearly 3,000 unaccompanied minors at a time were confined between June 2018 and January 2019. In this harsh environment, the Chihuahuan Desert, imagination and faith helped them make it through.

headline: When Corporate Lobbies Started to Look Like Museum Galleries
abstract: Big business loves to flash cultural credentials
lead_paragraph: The Seagram liquor company and the ancient Mesoamerican civilization of the Olmecs were not obvious bedfellows. But in 1965, a crane operator lowered a colossal Olmec sculpture of a head onto the corporation’s Manhattan doorstep. The artwork was awe-inspiring enough that its next stop was the World’s Fair, but, for a time, it sat in front of Seagram’s new Mies van der Rohe skyscraper on Park Avenue. Hosting the sculpture was an audacious move on the company’s part. The juxtaposition of the Olmecs’ pockmarked basalt and the building’s sleek glass and bronze exterior made a statement about where mankind had been and where it was going. Also, intentionally or not, it was a pretty epic pun on the phrase “how to get ahead in business.”

headline: 2 South African Presidents Are Called to Account on Corruption
abstract: President Cyril Ramaphosa was accused on Friday of misleading Parliament about a campaign donation after his predecessor, Jacob Zuma, was called to testify in a corruption hearing.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — South Africans witnessed the extraordinary spectacle this week of having both the president and his predecessor publicly called to account on accusations of corruption — charges that are also escalating a power struggle within the long-governing African National Congress.

headline: Philippine Vice President, a Duterte Foe, Is Charged in Plot Against Him
abstract: Vice President Leni Robredo was among 36 people charged in what opponents called a trumped-up case to discredit the president’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The police have charged members of the Philippine political opposition — including the country’s vice president — with sedition and other offenses for reportedly plotting to oust President Rodrigo Duterte, charges they described Friday as harassment to intimidate critics of the increasingly autocratic leader.

headline: The Rise of the Spice Girls Generation
abstract: Their fans are old enough to take over the world, just as the Spice Girls are back.
lead_paragraph: When, through the nighttime murk of the Amazon River, an electric eel locates a feeder fish, what happens next is instantaneous: A jolt of electricity surges through the fish’s nerves. Its muscles contract simultaneously, and it is transformed into a living, floating statue.

headline: First an E-ZPass, Then the Diamond Ring
abstract: Millicent Cooley was resigned to being single, but her attitude changed after meeting Anthony Duncan, a professional juggler. Their romance soon hit the road.
lead_paragraph: The night Millicent Cooley celebrated her 58th birthday and Anthony Duncan dropped to one knee and pulled out a small box from his pocket, party guests held their breath.

headline: Send Me Back to the Country I Came From
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Irish-Americans']
abstract: Ireland, the country of my ancestors, has become what America used to be.
lead_paragraph: He’s right, this angry old man in melting bronzer shouting in the July heat: Those of us who don’t like what’s going on in this country should get the hell out. “Go back,” as he said, to the “crime-infested places from which they came.” A fine idea.

headline: Defenders of a Racist President Use Jews as Human Shields
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Zionism', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump’s bigoted attack on four congresswomen of color has nothing to do with fighting anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Gorka, a onetime adviser to Donald Trump, wore a medal from the Vitezi Rend, a Hungarian group historically aligned with Nazism, to one of Trump’s inaugural balls. Gorka was reportedly a member of the group, whose founder, the Hungarian autocrat Miklos Horthy, once said, “For all my life, I have been an anti-Semite.”

headline: What to Do in New York This Weekend
abstract: “The Lion King” remake, the Apollo 11 anniversary and more: Here’s your guide to the weekend in culture.
lead_paragraph: “If a movie could be judged solely on technique, ‘The Lion King’ might qualify as a great one. And it kind of wants to be judged that way — for its technical skin rather than its dramatic soul,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review of the new super-realistic version of the Disney favorite. Once the voices start up (and these are some voices: Beyoncé, Donald Glover and Seth Rogen, to name a few), he added, “we are in a comfortable and familiar pop-cultural space, even if the talking beasts don’t look much like cartoons.”

headline: Private Surveillance Is a Lethal Weapon Anybody Can Buy
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Arms Trade', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Privacy', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Is it too late to rein it in?
lead_paragraph: The plan was simple: Give the government of Uzbekistan the ability to monitor everyone’s communications.

headline: How Much Beyoncé Does ‘The Lion King’ Have?
abstract: The superstar is all over the 2019 remake’s promotional tour. But how much of her will you hear in the actual film? We counted her lines.
lead_paragraph: To hear Beyoncé speak is such a rare occurrence that any new instance of it, no matter how fleeting, feels special, like catching a glimpse of a shooting star. So naturally, her involvement with Disney’s remake of “The Lion King”— she voices the adult Nala and created a companion album featuring new music inspired by the movie — has dominated the film’s promotional tour, complete with a meeting between Queen Bey and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex,  at the British premiere.

headline: Stream These 11 Movies for the Apollo 11 Anniversary
keywords: ['Movies', 'Moon', 'Apollo Project', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Fifty years ago, humans set foot on the moon. These documentaries and feature films try to put that and other real-life space missions into context.
lead_paragraph: Portions of this were published previously in the March 3, 2019, article “Want More After ‘Apollo 11’? Here Are 5 Space Documentaries to Stream.”

headline: Netherlands Was 10 Percent Liable in Srebrenica Deaths, Top Dutch Court Finds
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Supreme Court reduced the state’s level of liability for damages in the deaths of 350 men and boys who were ordered out of a peacekeepers’ compound in 1995.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dutch Supreme Court on Friday upheld a decision that the Netherlands was partly responsible for the deaths of 350 Muslim men during the 1995 Srebrenica massacre, but it slashed the level of liability for the Dutch government that was established in an earlier ruling.

headline: Australia Calls on China to Release Detained Writer
abstract: Foreign Minister Marise Payne said Yang Hengjun, a Chinese-born Australian, should be released “if he is being detained for his political views.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government strongly rebuked Beijing on Friday for detaining one of its citizens, a writer who has called for liberalization in China, expressing concern over his welfare and calling for his release.

headline: Summer Flings
abstract: Benefits for the Parrish Art Museum and the Fisher Center at Bard College.
lead_paragraph: The Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y., held its midsummer party on July 13; Louise and Leonard Riggio were honored, along with Maya Lin. And the Fisher Center at Bard College held its summer gala on July 13 at Montgomery Place in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y; it was followed by a Club Cumming takeover of Spiegeltent, erected every summer at the Fisher Center.

headline: Langston Hughes Sings in ‘The Black Clown’
abstract: Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival presents a music-theater adaptation of one of the poet’s dramatic monologues.
lead_paragraph: “I feel that for the first time, I have met the South,” the poet Langston Hughes wrote in the winter of 1932, at the end of a monthslong, multistate reading tour designed to cultivate black audiences.

headline: Who Played Mozart When He Was New?
abstract: With orchestras rare in the early 19th century, today’s classics spread in quartet arrangements, a new recording shows.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard for us to imagine, living as we do in a world of omnipresent recordings and performances of the symphonic war horses of Beethoven, Haydn and Mozart. But these pieces were once rarities.

headline: A Rarity for Poul Ruders: A Feel-Good Opera
abstract: The composer of a bleak “Handmaid’s Tale” adaptation brings a lighter, more lyrical fairy tale to Santa Fe Opera.
lead_paragraph: “My maternal grandfather, who was a humble gardener, loved Verdi and Puccini,” the Danish composer Poul Ruders recalled recently. “And when I was 10 or 11, he took me first to see ‘La Bohème,’ and then to see ‘Aida.’”

headline: New Members Flood U.K.’s Conservatives, Yanking the Party Right
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: A party of 160,000 paying members has had roughly 40,000 joiners in the past year. That has raised questions about whether this new wave helped radicalize the party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A year ago, John Rawlins joined the Conservative Party with a mission: to inject some zeal for a no-deal Brexit into a party then wary of it.

headline: Angela Merkel ‘Feels Solidarity’ for Congresswomen Targeted by Trump
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The chancellor said the president’s “go back” comment ran counter to her impression of what had made America strong.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany expressed solidarity on Friday with the four Democratic congresswomen whom President Trump told to “go back” to the countries they came from, saying the remarks ran counter to her impression of what makes America strong.

headline: Why the Democratic Debates Are Starting to Feel Like a Reality Show
abstract: The Democratic National Committee has all but encouraged performative breakout moments, and candidates must try to go viral or risk being left behind.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are fierce rivalries, long-tangled histories, deeply personal grudges — and in the end, only one winner can hold the rose.

abstract: As the two missed the cut at the same major tournament for the first time, other players started to tame Royal Portrush.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson have played a lot of golf together over the past two decades. But Friday brought something new for them. For the first time, Woods and Mickelson missed the cut at the same major tournament.

abstract: In New York, the calisthenics community is finding its rhythm.
lead_paragraph: In New York, the calisthenics community is finding its rhythm.

headline: What Is Behind the Protests in Puerto Rico?
abstract: Here is what you need to know about the eruption of street protests and popular anger at Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló and his administration.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, San Juan, P.R., is in turmoil. Growing numbers of angry protesters have been marching in the streets and converging on La Fortaleza, the official residence of Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló, where police officers in riot gear have fired tear gas, pepper spray and rubber bullets into the crowds.

headline: Back-to-School Sales Tax ‘Holidays’ Lure Shoppers Despite Slim Savings
keywords: ['Taxation', 'States (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: “People who won’t walk across the street to save $5 on a pair of pants will take a day off from work to take advantage of a sales-tax holiday,” a tax expert said.
lead_paragraph: If you missed out on the blitz of deals offered early this week by many online retailers, don’t despair: There may be additional savings on the horizon, as more than a dozen states gear up for their annual summer sales tax “holidays.”

headline: Feel Like You’re Being Stalked?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Brokers and other real estate marketers have ways to find you when you’re already under stress.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Aldrich Walsh said the onslaught started almost immediately after her husband’s obituary ran in the Houston Chronicle. Both she and her husband, Patrick Walsh, had come into their marriage owning homes, and they had been trying to sell his when he was diagnosed with brain cancer in June of last year; he died in November. That triggered an avalanche of contact from real estate investors wanting to buy one or both houses.

headline: Strong Earthquake Rattles Athens
abstract: A 5.1-magnitude earthquake prompted people in the Greek capital to flee buildings, though initial reports suggested no major injuries or damage.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A strong earthquake shook Athens on Friday afternoon, prompting panicked residents to flee office buildings and homes and pour into the streets of the city, though there were no immediate reports of any injuries or damage.

headline: A Onetime Star of Soviet TV Warns of the ‘Plague’ of Nationalism
abstract: Once a hero to Russian nationalists, Aleksandr G. Nevzorov has found a new cause and a growing audience in denouncing imperial fantasies.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — As a wildly popular television journalist when the Soviet Union was falling apart, Aleksandr G. Nevzorov took up a gun in January 1991 and joined the Soviet special forces on a violent but fruitless mission to stop Lithuania from breaking away.

headline: Everything You Need to Know for a Road Trip Up the Coast
abstract: Friday: If you need a summer getaway itinerary, we have you covered.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ASAP Rocky to Remain in Jail in Sweden, as Protest Clamor Grows
abstract: After a court said the rapper could be held at least six more days pending an assault investigation, President Trump said “we hope to get him home soon.”
lead_paragraph: It started as a quarrel on a quiet Stockholm street, but the case of ASAP Rocky, the rapper detained in Sweden on a preliminary charge of assault, has escalated into an international incident, with politicians and diplomats weighing in, and his celebrity backers pulling strings at the White House.

abstract: The postmodern Hamptons house was commissioned by the artist Norman Mercer in the 1970s and is on the market for $9.5 million.
lead_paragraph: An architectural alien dressed in shingles and passing itself off as just another roomy East Hampton beach house — no one will be fooled — is on the market at 33 Ocean Avenue for $9.5 million.

headline: Hong Kong’s Approach to Protesters: No More Concessions
abstract: Carrie Lam’s administration is confident that it can weather further demonstrations, despite recent violent clashes and signs that the economy could suffer.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s leader will not be making further concessions to the city’s protesters, two of her top advisers said, as the government digs in despite several large demonstrations over the past month and more planned for Sunday and the coming weeks.

headline: The Night Democracy Became the Lotto
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'Television', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: CNN’s hourlong debate-lineup revelation had the appearance of a Powerball drawing and just as much depth.
lead_paragraph: Democracy, as a certain other news outlet has famously observed, dies in darkness. But if you just want to beat it up and humiliate it for an hour, simply stick it in a box.

headline: Most Wikipedia Profiles Are of Men. This Scientist Is Changing That.
abstract: Jessica Wade has added nearly 700 Wikipedia biographies for important female and minority scientists in less than two years.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines.

headline: Marc Maron on ‘GLOW,’ His Podcast and ‘Sword of Trust’
abstract: The actor and host of “WTF” talks about hope and change and wrestling.
lead_paragraph: After four seasons of his namesake IFC comedy, and copious soul-searching, Marc Maron wasn’t clamoring for another series, let alone a character so neurotic, so angry and compulsive, so exactly like him. But when he first read the script for “GLOW,” and the role of Sam Sylvia — the dyspeptic B-movie director hired to create a TV show starring the Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling — he felt a jolt of connection.

headline: Hitler Looted the Art, Then They Looted Hitler
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: New research is helping the hunt for missing art, largely amassed by Hitler, then re-stolen by desperate Germans in the closing days of the war.
lead_paragraph: Chaos reigned in the bomb-ravaged streets of Munich on April 29, 1945. American troops were closing in. Hitler was a day away from killing himself in his bunker in Berlin. The Nazi guards who protected important buildings had fled.

headline: Polishing the Nationalist Brand in the Trump Era
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservative thinkers are trying to bring intellectual coherence to the Trumpian moment under the banner of nationalism. But can it be cleansed of its darker currents?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since Donald J. Trump laid waste to its ideological shibboleths with his victory at the polls, the conservative intellectual class has been scrambling to keep up with him.

headline: The Army’s Failure to Train and Equip Troops in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The recent deaths of U.S. service members in Afghanistan are part of a larger issue resulting from the Pentagon’s struggle to contend with multiple wars and new global threats at once.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: All Hail Samin Nosrat!
abstract: The beloved cookbook author’s latest recipe in The New York Times Magazine will change your cacio e pepe game.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Samin Nosrat has a beautiful column in The New York Times Magazine this week that sadly will be her last for at least the rest of the year, as she heads off into the world to travel, learn, eat and cook, in part so she can bring us a whole library of exciting new recipes when she returns.

headline: Iran’s Seizure of British Vessel Further Roils Gulf Region
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The seizure came a day after the United States said it had shot down an Iranian drone, reviving fears of a military clash in the Persian Gulf.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Iran seized at least one British oil tanker in a vital Persian Gulf waterway on Friday, a sharp escalation of tensions with the West that revived fears of a military clash, even as voices on both sides appeared to be seeking room for negotiations.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Price You Pay,’ ‘No Good Alternative’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE PRICE YOU PAY, by Aidan Truhen. (Vintage Crime/Black Lizard, $16.95.) When his elderly neighbor is killed, things start to go south for Jack Price, the slick cocaine dealer at the heart of this thriller. The book is “brilliant, a latticework of barbed jokes and subtle observations and inventive misbehaviors, a high-end thriller, relentlessly knowing, relentlessly brutal,” Charles Finch wrote in his review. “It reads like Martin Amis on mescaline.”

headline: A Ballerina Dislocates All Her Body Parts (Eyes Included)
abstract: Watch Maria Kochetkova perform part of her solo “Degunino,” choreographed by Marcos Morau.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Italy’s Government Parties Are Feuding, but Leaders Agree to Talk
abstract: The League party and Five Star Movement have been increasingly at odds, raising speculation that the coalition might collapse, forcing early elections.
lead_paragraph: After days of mounting political tension, the leading players in Italy’s bickering coalition government tried to steer their way to calmer waters on Friday, pledging to meet and discuss their differences in a bid to hold the government together.

headline: Why Have Novels About Royalty Stormed the Y.A. Best-Seller Lists?
abstract: Ruthless and treacherous, the characters in these books may be kings, queens and pawns, but they act a lot like the people at a teenager’s lunch table.
lead_paragraph: The cruelty is the point. If you’re looking to explain why today’s Y.A. best-seller lists are thick with kings, queens and fawning courts, think about why teenagers might be drawn to ambivalent heroes battling within or against the nasty, rigid structures of these monarchic worlds. We all have to know what we’re up against.

headline: Demands of Far-Right Party Unsettle Artists in Germany
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The anti-immigrant party Alternative for Germany wants to know the nationalities of artists employed by state theaters, and cultural organizations are worried.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — Elliott Carlton Hines, a baritone who sings with the Stuttgart State Opera, received a text message in June that unnerved him. A friend was telling him that the state culture ministry had been asked for the nationalities of artists employed in the state-funded opera, orchestra and ballet companies, as well as where they had been educated.

headline: N.F.L. Declines to Suspend Tyreek Hill After Domestic Violence Investigation
abstract: The Kansas City Chiefs wide receiver had been barred from team activities since April.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has chosen not to suspend Kansas City Chiefs wide receiver Tyreek Hill after a woman identified as his fiancée accused him of hitting their 3-year-old son earlier this year.

headline: For the Hottest Grilled Chicken, Double the Spices
abstract: Ground into the marinade and cracked whole on top, the spices in this Indian dish give it its heat and crunch.
lead_paragraph: In most renditions of bhatti da murgh (Punjabi grilled chicken), the spices are something you taste but do not feel. Ground into a powder and mixed into the marinade, they slip quietly onto your tongue, almost without warning, before bursting into a fireball of musky, tangy, smoky flavors — the more pungent, the better.

headline: Returning to Lac Mégantic, a Scene of Great Disaster
abstract: As part of a series following up on disasters, The Times returned to Lac Mégantic, Quebec, where a train derailment killed 47 and recovery remains slow.
lead_paragraph: During my career, I’ve reported on several terrible events but the rail disaster in Lac Mégantic, Quebec six years ago is among the worst.

headline: As Conflict With U.S. Grows, Some Iran Hard-liners Suggest Talking to Trump
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The idea of engaging with the Trump administration is led by Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the ex-president known for his hard-line anti-American bombast.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s most revered Revolutionary Guards commander says talking with President Trump would be admitting defeat. The country’s supreme leader has ruled out any dealings with Washington.

headline: A Murderer Deemed Too Old for Violence Was Just Convicted of Another Killing
abstract: The 77-year-old man, who was free despite a long history of violence against women, was convicted of an attack nearly identical to his killing of his wife 40 years ago.
lead_paragraph: A murderer with a long history of violence against women — but who had been freed from prison and deemed unlikely to hurt anyone again because of his advancing age — was convicted by a jury in Maine this week in the stabbing death of a mother of twin boys.

headline: Donald Trump, and Other Readers, Had a Lot to Say About Friedman’s Column
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: More than 5,000 readers, including the president, weighed in.
lead_paragraph: Is it time for a revolution within the Democratic Party? “Spare me,” writes Thomas L. Friedman in his column, “‘Trump’s Going to Get Re-elected, Isn’t He?’”: “Win the presidency, hold the House and narrow the spread in the Senate, and a lot of good things still can be accomplished.”

headline: No More Manholes in Berkeley as City Writes Gender Out of Codes
abstract: Berkeley’s City Council this week voted to purge gender pronouns from its municipal code. He or she will be banished in favor of they, even if referring to one person.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The city of Berkeley, long a bastion of liberal ideas, voted this week to purge gender from its law books.

headline: Four Chicago Police Officers Fired for Cover-Up of Laquan McDonald Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: After high-profile police shootings, the legal and disciplinary process can play out for years. Only in rare instances do officers face charges.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — On an autumn night in 2014, a black teenager named Laquan McDonald was shot dead by a Chicago police officer. Nearly five years later, on Thursday, a city oversight board voted to fire four other officers accused of covering up the circumstances of Laquan’s death.

headline: L. Bruce Laingen, Senior Hostage During Iran Crisis, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: A career diplomat, he had only recently arrived in Tehran for a temporary diplomatic posting when the embassy was seized in 1979.
lead_paragraph: L. Bruce Laingen, the highest-ranking American official held in Iran during the 444-day-long hostage ordeal that began there in November 1979, died on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 96.

abstract: “I didn’t invent the system. I just lived by the system.”
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t invent the system. I just lived by the system.”

headline: Ilhan Omar Returns to Minneapolis for Hero’s Welcome
abstract: After a week of attacks from President Trump and his supporters, Representative Ilhan Omar returned to her district Thursday night for a hero’s welcome.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — After a week of attacks by President Trump that culminated in a chant of “send her back” at one of his re-election rallies, Representative Ilhan Omar, the Somali-born Democrat from Minnesota, returned to her district on Thursday evening to a hero’s welcome.

headline: The Playlist: Miranda Lambert Stomps Back, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Wilco, Sam Smith, Iggy Pop and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Trump’s Electoral College Edge Could Grow in 2020, Rewarding Polarizing Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Electoral College', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Re-election looks plausible even with a bigger loss in the national popular vote.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s approval ratings are under water in national polls. His position for re-election, on the other hand, might not be quite so bleak.

headline: This Fruit Should Go in Everything
abstract: With chicken, pork or shrimp, on toast or in salad, peaches should be a part of your next meal.
lead_paragraph: I’m in the honeymoon phase of summer cooking, the golden time before I can’t even look at the six zucchini that are in permanent residence in my fridge. Right now I’m especially enamored of nectarines and peaches — for breakfast, for snacks, for dinner, for dessert. (Nectarines are in fact superior to peaches, but both are so much better than other summer fruit, with the possible exception of watermelon, that we should just think of them interchangeably here. Email me at dearemily@nytimes.com if you have feelings about this!)

headline: New & Noteworthy Visual Books, From Maurice Sendak’s Stage Sets to Dogs in Space
abstract: A selection of recent visual books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: DRAWING THE CURTAIN: Maurice Sendak’s Designs for Opera and Ballet, by Rachel Federman. (Prestel, with DelMonico Books and the Morgan Library & Museum, $40.) The late great children’s book author may have been most famous for “Where the Wild Things Are,” but it turns out he also harbored a passion for music and the stage, and designed sets for productions including “The Nutcracker” and Mozart’s “The Magic Flute.”

headline: America Is So Hot That ...
abstract: Sweaty snapshots from across the country.
lead_paragraph: FROST, Tex. — America is hot. Really hot. So hot that even here in a town named Frost perspiration flows.

headline: Fresh Beans Come Out of Their Shell
abstract: Paired with an assertive vinaigrette and a very peppery lamb, they’re, quite simply, sensational.
lead_paragraph: Summer cooking is all about fresh vegetables. It’s the season for salads, leafy and otherwise. Nearly every offering at the produce stand qualifies.

headline: Sheriff to Investigate Jeffrey Epstein ‘Work Release’ After Allegation of Nude Meeting
abstract: Mr. Epstein was allowed to leave jail to work. A lawyer recently said that he used that privilege for “improper sexual contact,” and a Florida sheriff has opened an internal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff in Florida ordered an internal investigation Friday into whether deputies violated any rules while monitoring Jeffrey Epstein, the wealthy New York financier, on a work-release program a decade ago.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Tweet About Too-High Interest Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The Federal Reserve raised rates specifically because the United States economy was stronger than its global counterparts.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has made a regular habit of criticizing the Federal Reserve, and on Friday he tweeted that the central bank’s “faulty” decision-making was causing Americans to pay higher interest rates than other nations.

headline: Time for Another Trip to the Moon?
abstract: A reporter who covered the Apollo 11 lunar mission 50 years ago and other readers offer their opinions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 75 Years After World War II Theft, a Painting Returns to Italy
abstract: Italy successfully pressed the heirs of a German soldier who had stolen a painting to give it back, with a little help from diplomats and social media.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Compared to showier works in Florence’s Pitti Palace — paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael, and Titian — the small “Vase of Flowers” by Jan van Huysum might barely earn a second glance, even if the artist was among the most popular still-life artists working in the Netherlands in the 18th century.

headline: Suicide Bombing at University Kills 10 as Violence Surges in Afghanistan
abstract: Despite a pledge to reduce civilian casualties, the Taliban have intensified attacks that kill civilians as well as soldiers.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As law students waited outside Kabul University to take fourth-year exams shortly after daybreak on Friday, a suicide bomber drove up and detonated an explosive device, killing 10 people and wounding 33.

headline: Texas Legalized Hemp, Not Marijuana, Governor Insists as Prosecutors Drop Pot Charges
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Marijuana', 'Hemp', 'Politics and Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Prosecutors say labs don’t have the time or equipment to distinguish between legal hemp and illegal pot.
lead_paragraph: Texas lawmakers thought they were clear: The bill they overwhelmingly passed allowing the growth and sale of hemp had nothing to do with legalizing pot.

headline: New York Live Arts Lineup Puts the Focus on Community
abstract: “We’re asking the question: ‘Where is the poetry in social change,’” said Bill T. Jones.
lead_paragraph: For Bill T. Jones and Janet Wong, the artistic leaders at New York Live Arts, community is a pressing political concern. The lineup they chose for the organization’s coming season is meant to reflect that urgency and highlight the role that art can play in examining societal problems.

headline: Fed’s Bullard Says He Would Take Chair Job, if Ever Offered It
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, also said he prefers a 0.25 percentage-point cut at the Fed’s next meeting.
lead_paragraph: James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, said he would “love” to lead the central bank if given the chance.

headline: The Joy of Hatred
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Lynching', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump and “his people” reach deep into the violent history of public spectacle in America.
lead_paragraph: The chanting was disturbing and the anger was frightening, but what I noticed most about the president’s rally in Greenville, N.C., on Wednesday night was the pleasure of the crowd.

headline: Netflix Wants to Make Its Dubbed Foreign Shows Less Dubby
abstract: The company is betting that better English versions of international hits like “Money Heist” will inspire more Americans to watch them.
lead_paragraph: In June, the actress Ayelet Zurer stood at a microphone in a Los Angeles recording studio, reading English dialogue aloud as it scrolled, karaoke-like, under scenes of Netflix’s Spanish crime drama “La Casa de Papel,” or “Money Heist.”

headline: N.S.A. Contractor Who Hoarded Secrets at Home Is Sentenced to Nine Years in Prison
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The case of Harold T. Martin III, who took home classified material undetected for nearly 20 years, was a major embarrassment for security officials.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A troubled former National Security Agency contractor who spent two decades stuffing his home, car and garden shed with highly classified documents was sentenced on Friday to nine years in prison in a case that exposed a shocking laxity in security at the N.S.A. and other secret government facilities.

headline: Tay-K, Rapper Who Went Viral With ‘The Race,’ Is Found Guilty of Murder
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The 19-year-old musician, who released a hit single while on the run from the authorities, faces up to 99 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Taymor McIntyre, a Texas teenager best known as the rapper Tay-K (or Tay-K 47), was found guilty of murder on Friday for his role in a 2016 armed robbery that left one man dead and, in a controversial series of events, helped to kick-start Tay-K’s brief, viral rise in hip-hop.

headline: Meghan McCain: What I Learned From My Miscarriage
abstract: I loved my baby, and I always will.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I was part of the photo shoot for The New York Times Magazine’s cover story about ABC’s “The View.” It should have been a moment of triumph — a vindication of the show’s significance as a place at the center of political debate, a ratings boom, a must for the top tier of presidential candidates. I should have been proud. I knew my father would have been proud.

headline: Trump, ‘Exploiting Racism for Political Gain’

abstract: Readers discuss the president’s “go back” tweet and reflect on earlier calls of “America, love it or leave it.”

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Saving Notre-Dame. John Paul Stevens dies. 16,000 Readers on “go back.” 16 black chefs changing food in the U.S. Generation Spice Girls. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Much of the U.S. is feeling the full wrath of a heat wave. The House condemned President Trump’s attack on four freshmen congresswomen as racist. And we saw Novak Djokovic win Wimbledon in one of the greatest matches in history. Here are some other stories you may have missed.

headline: Does Russia Want More Than Your Old Face?
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: The FaceApp fracas forces us to think hard about giving our personal data to companies in authoritarian countries.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — Hey, America, Vladimir Putin wants to steal your face. Or maybe not!

headline: Colson Whitehead Talks About ‘The Nickel Boys’
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize winner discusses his new novel, and Jon Gertner talks about “The Ice at the End of the World.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Intelligence Chief Names New Election Security Oversight Official
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Elections']
abstract: A newly created post will oversee intelligence collection and analysis on foreign influence campaigns and efforts to attack election infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — An experienced official will oversee election security intelligence across the government in a newly created senior position, the director of national intelligence announced on Friday as part of an effort to improve coordination and speed response to attacks by foreign governments.

headline: The Loudness of João Gilberto, Bossa Nova’s King of Quiet
abstract: A look back at the Brazilian musician’s innovations as one of the genre’s primary architects.
lead_paragraph: João Gilberto, whose death at 88 was announced earlier this month, was the father of bossa nova — the terse, intimate and cosmopolitan sound that took over Brazil in the late 1950s and helped set the agenda for the global pop of the early 1960s. In 1965, “Getz/Gilberto,” an album he made with the American jazz saxophonist Stan Getz, won the Grammy for album of the year.

headline: Morehouse College Investigates Sexual Misconduct After Students’ Videos
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: In widely shared videos, two students accused a staff member at the all-male, historically black school of sexual harassment. The college has expanded its investigation to other employees.
lead_paragraph: The first video detailing allegations of sexual misconduct came with a plea: “Please get Morehouse’s attention.”

headline: Arthur Ryan, Who Founded the Low-Cost Fashion Chain Primark, Dies at 83
abstract: By keeping costs down and prices affordable, Mr. Ryan grew the company from one store in Dublin into an international retail behemoth.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ryan, the chairman and founder of Primark, the low-cost fashion chain that began as a single store in Dublin and grew into an international retailing giant, died on July 8 at his home in Ballsbridge, Ireland.  He was 83.

headline: A Seemingly Impossible Challenge
abstract: After reaching out to 30 people, we met Herminia.
lead_paragraph: For Monday’s show, producer Jessica Cheung took on a seemingly impossible challenge: find an undocumented immigrant who had defied a deportation order and was willing to talk about it in a recorded conversation that would reach 2 million listeners.

headline: D.I.Y. Private Equity Is Luring Small Investors
abstract: Amateur investors are setting up high-risk, high-return deals on their own, but the key to success varies.
lead_paragraph: Private equity funds have performed well in the last few years, returning 10 percent in 2018 alone, beating all other indexes.

headline: Aaron Boone Suspended One Game for Tirade Against Umpire
abstract: M.L.B. announced the decision on Friday, one day after Boone furiously confronted the umpire Brennan Miller over his ball-and-strike calls.
lead_paragraph: Yankees Manager Aaron Boone was suspended for one game and fined an undisclosed amount for his profanity-laced outburst at the home plate umpire Brennan Miller on Thursday, Major League Baseball announced.

headline: Leana Wen: Why I Left Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I believe abortion is about health care, not politics. Many of my colleagues disagreed.
lead_paragraph: This week, I left my position as the president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood.

headline: Coming Soon to a Theater Near You. Very Soon.
abstract: Hollywood’s top three marketers — Walt Disney Studios, Warner Bros. and Universal Pictures — say marathon marketing campaigns no longer make sense for most movies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Conventional wisdom in Hollywood has long held that big, lumbering “tentpole” movies require protracted promotional campaigns.

headline: Jussie Smollett Fights Appointment of Special Prosecutor
abstract: The “Empire” actor’s lawyers want a new judge to decide on whether an investigator should revisit charges that he staged a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Jussie Smollett asked a Chicago court on Friday to reconsider a decision to appoint a special prosecutor to re-examine the case against the actor, who was accused of staging a hate crime before prosecutors abruptly dropped the charges.

headline: Ida Wyman, Whose Camera Captured Ordinary People, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Wyman photographed for Life, Business Week and her own enjoyment, satisfying “an immense curiosity to learn and understand the lives of others.”
lead_paragraph: Ida Wyman, a photographer who in the 1940s and ’50s roamed New York and other cities to capture compelling images of everyday people working, playing, idling, dancing or selling newspapers, died on July 13 in Fitchburg, Wis., near Madison. She was 93.

headline: At the Tour de France, Some Just Try to Survive to Ride Another Day
abstract: A time trial. A chase car. A wild ride at the Tour de France.
lead_paragraph: PAU, France — So on a lark, a chance encounter, I have ended up in the chase car for Natnael Berhane, an Eritrean cyclist, as he twists and turns and pedals like a banshee along a 16.9-mile time trial through the foothills of the Pyrenees.

headline: For 50 Years Since Apollo 11, Presidents Have Tried to Take That Next Giant Leap
keywords: ['Moon', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Apollo Project', 'Mars (Planet)', 'International Space Station', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump is only the latest to propose returning to the moon and then heading to Mars. But he faces the burdens of history to accomplish what his predecessors could not.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At his star-spangled Independence Day extravaganza this month, President Trump singled out Gene Kranz, the legendary Apollo flight director. “Gene,” the president said, “I want you to know that we’re going to be back on the moon very soon — and someday soon, we will plant the American flag on Mars.”

headline: House Democrats Prepare for Civil War as Challengers Plot Primary Battles
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Several entrenched New York representatives will face progressive hopefuls seeking to replicate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s success.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Marine Corps Orders Duncan Hunter to Stop Using Emblem on Political Mailers
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Logos', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: The mailer, which attacked his opponent and other representatives as radicals and anti-Semites, had used the Marines’ Eagle, Globe and Anchor emblem.
lead_paragraph: Representative Duncan Hunter wore the United States Marine Corps’ iconic Eagle, Globe and Anchor emblem on his uniform for years when he deployed multiple times to Iraq and Afghanistan. But that evidently did not give him license to put it on his campaign materials more than a decade later.

headline: Mariano Rivera’s Priceless (and Pricey) Gifts on Display at Cooperstown
abstract: His autographed ball sells for $699 at the gift shop. But there is another on display that is priceless.
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — They stretch across the front row of a display case at the official Hall of Fame gift shop, autographed baseballs in plastic boxes from the five living players to be inducted on Sunday. Edgar Martinez’s ball goes for $249, Mike Mussina’s for $199 and Harold Baines’s and Lee Smith’s for $149 each.

headline: ‘Uncontrollable’ Jeffrey Epstein: 5 Takeaways From Judge’s Bail Decision
abstract: Mr. Epstein was willing to pay almost anything to stay out of jail. But the judge suggested he could not curb his sexual fixation with minors.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Elusive Emu Remains at Large in North Carolina After More Than Three Weeks
abstract: Animal control officials in Orange County, N.C., haven’t seen an emu on the loose in a decade. An owner has not yet come forward to claim the emu.
lead_paragraph: It’s 5 feet tall, weighs 100 pounds and has been running loose in central North Carolina for more than three weeks.

headline: Marylou Whitney, Social Queen of the Racing World, Dies at 93
abstract: A fixture in Saratoga and Lexington, she was a prominent hostess, a patron of the arts and, not least, a sportswoman and a thoroughbred breeder.
lead_paragraph: Marylou Whitney, who fled Missouri for New York with dreams of being an actress and found instead a life of immense wealth and privilege, marrying into two of America’s richest families and reigning for decades as the social queen of the Saratoga and Lexington racing seasons, died on Friday at her home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. She was 93.

headline: A Plate Adjustment Helped D.J. LeMahieu With Yankees, and Skeptical Fans
abstract: The Yankees infielder stopped narrowly focusing on powerful drives to left field, and as a result won over those puzzled by the deal that brought him to New York.
lead_paragraph: Whenever infielder D.J. LeMahieu has one of the performances the Yankees have come to rely on this season — a multi-hit game with several runs driven in — the tweet officially announcing his signing on Jan. 14 resurfaces as a playful reminder of how much has changed.

headline: How to Save the Amazon Rain Forest
abstract: Countries in the Amazon Basin are falling behind on their targets to cut deforestation. Environmental enforcement combined with economic incentives could provide a way forward.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the Amazon region, human activities like agricultural production, infrastructure development and logging are leading to alarming levels of deforestation. After impressive advances like the tripling of protected areas in Colombia, we are now seeing backsliding or insufficient improvement throughout the basin. Policies that are sound on paper often succumb to the combination of weak institutions and inadequate enforcement coupled with powerful economic forces, both legal and illegal, driving activities that destroy forests.

headline: Puerto Ricans Deserve Better From Their Government
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Governors (US)', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Hurricane Maria (2017)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A local leadership scandal has exacerbated recent struggles on the island.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans have taken to the streets of San Juan to let their government leaders — and the world — know that they have had enough.

headline: 3,271 Pill Bottles, a Town of 2,831: Court Filings Say Corporations Fed Opioid Epidemic
abstract: Cities and counties are suing major drugstore chains and Walmart, contending they distributed billions of painkillers that devastated communities.
lead_paragraph: The Walgreens employee was bewildered by the quantity of opioids the company was shipping to just one store. Its pharmacy in Port Richey, Fla. (population 2,831) was ordering 3,271 bottles of oxycodone a month.

headline: Angus McQueen, the N.R.A.’s Image Maker, Dies at 74
abstract: He was a principal architect of the N.R.A.’s modern image, until an astonishing legal battle between his firm and the gun group broke out.
lead_paragraph: Angus McQueen, whose Midwest advertising agency was a principal architect of the National Rifle Association’s modern image until the firm had a remarkable falling out with the gun group this year, died on Tuesday in Oklahoma City. He was 74.

headline: Subway Service Is Suspended on Several Lines, M.T.A. Says
abstract: Passengers were left stranded on subways and platforms during the evening rush on the first day of a heat wave.
lead_paragraph: Subway passengers were left stranded and broiling on train platforms for more than an hour on Friday night on the first day of a heat wave as several lines in New York City were suspended in both directions.

headline: For Li Na, Another First in Tennis
abstract: On Saturday, she will be the first Asian-born player to be inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: When Li Na was a girl, tennis was often an objectionable chore. Training was grueling, her coaches berated her, and sometimes she hated it.

headline: Trump’s Labor Pick Has Defended Corporations, and One Killer Whale
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Eugene Scalia, whom Mr. Trump plans to nominate as labor secretary, has been a go-to lawyer for businesses like UPS and SeaWorld.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Scalia, whom President Trump intends to nominate as labor secretary, is often hired by companies when they are sued by workers, or when they want to push back against new employment laws and regulations.

headline: In Another About-Face, Trump Refuses to Condemn ‘Send Her Back’ Chant
abstract: After saying he was “not happy” with the “send her back” chant at his rally in North Carolina, President Trump reversed himself, just as he did in 2017 after the violence in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday demonstrated the limited influence of allies or advisers who try to steer him away from pre-election racial and cultural fights. He walked back his disavowal of a racially loaded chant at a campaign rally less than 24 hours after making it.

headline: Inmates Freed as Justice Dept. Tries to Clear Hurdles of New Law
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Criminal Justice', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: More than 3,000 federal inmates were granted early release under the bipartisan criminal justice overhaul passed late last year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 3,000 inmates were freed from federal prison on Friday as part of the Justice Department’s implementation of the sweeping bipartisan criminal justice overhaul that President Trump signed into law late last year.

headline: One Huge Tennis Fine Is Overturned, Another Upheld
abstract: Anna Tatishvili won an appeal to reclaim her prize money from the French Open, where she lost in the first round and was accused of not performing at a proper level. A similar appeal by Bernard Tomic yielded only a meager concession.
lead_paragraph: Anna Tatishvili has won an appeal of one of the harshest penalties in tennis. After a 6-1, 6-0 loss to Maria Sakkari in the first round of the French Open in May, Tatishvili was fined all of her first-round prize money, 46,000 euros, or about $51,500, for failing to “perform to the required professional standard.”

headline: The Perfect Antidote to Trump
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Willa Cather knew what made America great.
lead_paragraph: When I was in high school I read Willa Cather’s “My Ántonia” and loved it for the love story it told. This week, I borrowed my daughter’s copy and read it again. It turns out to be a book for our times — and the perfect antidote to our president.

headline: What to Bring to Your Summer Rental
abstract: A vacation rental should come equipped with everything you’ll need, but here are five items that Wirecutter editors have learned to bring — just in case.
lead_paragraph: For a longer summer vacation — a week or two, say — renting a house or condo can beat staying at a hotel. You can cook instead of eating out; you have a comfy place to hang out on a rainy day. This place should in theory have all the essentials: kitchenware, bedding, entertainment system. But here are a few extra things you might want to pack, just in case.

headline: Equifax Is Said to Be Close to Reaching Deal in Huge ’17 Data Breach
abstract: The agreement, which calls for the company to pay around $650 million, is meant to resolve federal and state inquiries and consumer claims over the exposure of data of at least 145 million people.
lead_paragraph: The credit bureau Equifax is expected to pay around $650 million to settle federal and state investigations and consumer claims relating to a data breach that exposed sensitive information belonging to at least 145 million people, according to two people familiar with the settlement discussions.

headline: To the Moon, but Not Back
abstract: You might be surprised what humans left behind on the lunar surface.
lead_paragraph: Before Neil Armstrong could take his small step down to the surface of a new world, before he and Buzz Aldrin could plant the flag, or scoop up moon rocks, or bunny-hop across the desolate lunar landscape, the astronauts of Apollo 11 had to take out the trash.

headline: Appeals Court Judges Send Emoluments Suit Against Trump Back to a Lower Court
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A three-judge panel said a lower court judge hearing a lawsuit by congressional Democrats had not adequately considered questions about separation of powers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court delivered a setback on Friday to a lawsuit by congressional Democrats accusing President Trump of illegally benefiting from his business interests while in office, saying a lower court judge hearing the suit had not adequately considered questions about the separation of powers between the president and Congress.

headline: Trump and Ahmadinejad Are Right
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Gulf of Oman Incident (June 2019)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The administration is talking to the Taliban and North Korea. Why not Iran?
lead_paragraph: “President Donald Trump and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad are on the same page” is something only a science fiction writer would have typed before the summer of 2019.

headline: Big Times
abstract: Sam Trabucco’s puzzle toys with us a little.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I had a hunch, and sure enough his notes reveal that there is a lot of Sam Trabucco in this Sam Trabucco puzzle today. It’s cool — Mr. Trabucco is an interesting guy. There are a lot of debuts in this grid, including those two crossing span entries; a couple are surprises (TOP FORTY, really?) and a bunch are those one-offs that are common in a personality-laden themeless like this.

headline: Eight Artists Withdraw From Whitney Biennial Over Board Member’s Ties to Tear Gas
keywords: ['Whitney Biennial', 'Tear Gas', 'Art', 'Museums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The artists cited the museum’s “inertia” over calls to remove Warren B. Kanders.
lead_paragraph: Eight artists have asked the Whitney Museum of American Art to remove their works from this year’s Biennial, citing what they describe as the museum’s lack of response to calls for the resignation of a board member with ties to the sale of military supplies, including tear gas.

headline: ‘What You Gonna Do Phone the Police?’ London Police Twitter Is Hacked
abstract: For about 40 minutes on Friday, the account spewed a series of curious messages, including some that used profanity to denigrate police officers.
lead_paragraph: For the Twitter feed of London’s Metropolitan Police, Friday seemed like an ordinary day.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 50 Years After Apollo 11, the Moon Seems to Grow Farther Away
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 20, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “The problem is it’s easy to say, ‘Let’s go back to the moon and Mars,’ but as they used to say in NASA — ‘No bucks, no Buck Rogers.’ ”

headline: Corrections: July 20, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, July 20, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Movies About the Moon Landing
abstract: Celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing with “First Man,” “For All Mankind” and more.
lead_paragraph: FIRST MAN (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. While this Oscar-winning drama about Neil Armstrong touches on the space race and the political issues the moon landing raised at home, it focuses on the personal and professional setbacks Armstrong overcame before taking that small step in 1969. “Feelings are the film’s fuel,” A.O. Scott wrote in his New York Times review. “Like some of the ancient epics ‘First Man’ is primarily a character study, a space odyssey with a diffident and enigmatic Ulysses at its center." Ryan Gosling, collaborating with “La La Land” director Damien Chazelle for the second time, portrays the astronaut in the years leading up to the Apollo 11 launch. The screenplay draws from James R. Hansen’s biography and contrasts Armstrong’s reserved, hard-to-read temperament with the larger-than-life job he has shouldered. We watch as he and his wife (Claire Foy) grieve over the loss of their daughter, prepare for the launch and wrestle with the fact that Armstrong could go down in history as the first man to walk on the moon — or perish in outer space.

headline: The Week in Arts: Lalah Hathaway, Clay Play and ‘Douglas’
abstract: Burt Lancaster is celebrated nearly 40 different ways; “Mum” crosses the pond; and a fierce, fiddling Finn, Pekka Kuusisto, comes to town.
lead_paragraph: July 19; filmforum.org and filmlinc.org

headline: CBS Is Blacked Out for 6.5 Million AT&T Customers. Here’s Why.
abstract: CBS and AT&T couldn’t agree on licensing fees and streaming rights. DirecTV, U-verse and DirecTVNow customers in 14 markets can’t watch CBS.
lead_paragraph: CBS, the nation’s most-watched television network, went dark for more than 6.5 million AT&T customers early Saturday after the two media giants couldn’t agree on a new contract.

headline: For Some Players, Not Reaching the Hall Just Brings More Fame
abstract: Baseball has kept certain players at arm’s length because of scandals and accusations, but that often has bolstered the players’ popularity.
lead_paragraph: Shoeless Joe Jackson was, by any measure, the top contributor for the Chicago White Sox in the World Series 100 years ago. With his trademark coiled swing, he tallied a dozen hits and Chicago’s lone home run in a five-games-to-three loss to the Cincinnati Reds that October.

headline: Cesar Pelli, Designer of Iconic Buildings Around the World, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Pelli, whose many distinctive projects include the Petronas Twin Towers in Malaysia, tried to reconcile modernism with his interest in shape, texture and the architecture of the past.
lead_paragraph: Cesar Pelli, who designed some of the world’s most recognizable buildings, died on Friday at his home in New Haven. He was 92.

headline: Workers in Spain’s Strawberry Fields Speak Out on Abuse
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Strawberries', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Human Trafficking']
abstract: Ten Moroccan women who worked as pickers have filed suits complaining of sexual harassment and assault, rape, human trafficking and labor violations.
lead_paragraph: ALMONTE, Spain — A little over a year ago, a young mother left her children in the care of her husband in Morocco and went to work on a strawberry farm near the city of Almonte, on Spain’s southwestern coast.

headline: Lugging the British Open Across the Irish Sea
abstract: Tournament organizers ferried everything from scoreboards to grandstands to give Northern Ireland the look and feel of a proper major.

headline: The Vicious Fun of America’s Most Famous Literary Circle
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', "Women's Rights", 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The Algonquin Round Table trained a generation of socially conscious writers.
lead_paragraph: This year is the 100th anniversary of the first meeting of the Algonquin Round Table, one of the 20th century’s most famous literary gatherings. The story has become a part of New York City lore: In June 1919, a group of writers and critics gathered at the Algonquin Hotel, at 59 West 44th Street in Midtown Manhattan, to welcome the critic Alexander Woollcott home from the war. What started as an impromptu lunch (at two square tables pushed together; the round table came a year later) proved to be such delicious fun that the group returned at 1 p.m., and practically every day thereafter, inviting new lunch companions, until it dissolved in the early 1930s.

At that moment, seeing what women like me were able to achieve, I became convinced that my own political aspirations could become a reality.

headline: FaceApp and the Savage Shock of Aging
abstract: In the mirror is someone we never thought we’d become.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago I was in a department store, frazzled and running late, looking for things I couldn’t find. As I was hastening along an aisle, a woman came toward me. She was quite a bit older than I was, and in a state of substantial disarray. As I drew closer I saw her shirt was wrongly buttoned. I put up a hand to prevent her bumping into me, and she put up a hand as well. I stopped. She stopped. We stared at each other with a kind of pity. And with a sudden rush of mortification, I understood that I was looking at myself in a mirror. Was I that tired and shambolic? Was I that old?

headline: The Ridiculous Fantasy of a ‘No Drama’ Relationship
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Mobile Applications', 'Women and Girls', 'Online Dating', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Online, that’s what men say they want from women. Do they know nothing about life?
lead_paragraph: I was recently on the dating app Bumble when I came across the profile of an attractive middle-aged man, a few years younger than I am. He was born on the East Coast and had a big dog, which I liked. But then I read that he was “100 percent drama-free” and demanded that any dates be the same way. I thought, “Here’s somebody who probably won’t listen if I’m having a bad day” and swiped left to indicate my lack of interest.

headline: How Democrats Defeat Donald Trump
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Stop talking so much about the America that he’s destroying. Save your breath for the America you want to create.
lead_paragraph: Surprise, surprise: Donald Trump has no bottom. Just when you think he has sunk as low as he can, he stages a rally like that atrocity in North Carolina on Wednesday night and sinks lower. But the key takeaway isn’t that he’s a demagogue or a racist: These were facts put into evidence long ago. It’s that Democrats can’t afford to take unnecessary risks, dream deferrable dreams and engage in avoidable distractions as they set about the urgent work of defeating him. The 2020 election isn’t about getting everything that Democrats want and that Americans deserve. It’s about getting rid of Trump, because the price of not doing so could be this nation’s very soul.

So it was with some curiosity that I found myself and a colleague some months ago headed toward the site of what was once the world’s largest garbage dump — Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island — to look at trees.

headline: The Flaws of the Great Justice Stevens
abstract: Fine personal qualities do not always translate into judicial virtues.
lead_paragraph: Like so many others, I was saddened to learn of the passing of Justice John Paul Stevens. He was a fellow Midwesterner, honest, self-effacing and kind, but with a strong independent streak and a passion for justice. I had the privilege of interviewing with him for a clerkship once, and then observing him up close for a year as I clerked for Chief Justice William Rehnquist. He was the quintessential gentleman and scholar.
